You are moderately happy (level 7 on a scale of 1-10), and while you are not very concerned about issues such as job loss, unemployment, or a lack of good education for your children, you are clear about your belief in maintaining a stable, orderly society. You have confidence in the police, courts, and banks, and you trust the people you know personally. You also value the importance of loyalty and trust within your family, feeling that you trust your family completely.

Your overall worldview is cautious yet optimistic. You believe in personal responsibility but also understand the need for some government involvement to ensure fairness and equality. Your belief in freedom, security, and economic growth shapes your approach to life and governance. You feel a strong connection to your country, but you are open to social change, even if it is through revolutionary means. Ultimately, you want a society that is humane, equitable, and offers opportunities for personal and collective growth.
70285:
You were born in country 608 and currently live here, regularly sharing your household with seven other people, making up a household of eight. You have a strong sense of pride in your country and feel very close to it. Family plays an important role in your life, and your parents are both from this country, with your father hailing from country 608. You are male, and although you are single and without children, you believe that having children is a duty towards society.

Religion is a significant part of your life, and you identify as a Roman Catholic. You attend religious services more than once a week, and you strongly believe that God is extremely important in your life. You think the basic meaning of religion is to do good to other people, rather than adhering strictly to religious norms or ceremonies. Additionally, you consider yourself a religious person and you believe in life after death. You also maintain that when science and religion conflict, religion is always right. Your faith is at the heart of your worldview, and you hold that the meaning of religion is not just about life after death, but about making sense of life in this world.

Politically, you are somewhat involved, as you are actively involved in a political party and sometimes discuss political matters with friends. However, politics is not very important in your life overall. You are a member of a church or religious organization, though not highly active. You have a neutral stance on some aspects of democracy, like whether women having the same rights as men is essential to democracy. Still, you firmly believe that choosing leaders in free elections is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy, a view you strongly hold (level 10). You are also largely satisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country (level 7).

You feel that political violence is never justified, and you strongly oppose any form of terrorism. At the same time, you have concerns about the fairness of elections, noting that votes are not often counted fairly and that election officials are not always fair. You believe that the press often favors the governing party and that journalists don't always provide fair coverage of elections. Corruption is a major issue for you, and you believe there is abundant corruption in your country, as well as in most of the local and state authorities. You don't trust the police, courts, or political parties much either.

Regarding your views on governance, you do not support a democratic political system as a way of governing your country. You find the idea of a system governed by religious law without political parties or elections fairly good. You also believe it would be fairly bad to have a democratic political system in your country, and you feel it would be quite beneficial to have a strong leader who doesn't have to bother with parliament and elections. Despite this, you also feel that maintaining order in the nation is most important and that protecting freedom of speech is the second most crucial goal for your country.

You consider equality more important than freedom, and you believe that a high level of economic growth should be a primary goal for the country. However, you do recognize the importance of environmental protection, even if it means slower economic growth and job losses. You are also concerned about the state of the economy and the potential risks of unemployment and job loss, worrying about these issues quite a lot. You feel moderately secure these days but are cautious about possible threats.

Your relationship with the outside world reflects a certain caution. You trust people from another religion somewhat and have mixed feelings about foreigners coming to your country. While you believe that immigration fills important job vacancies, you think the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners allowed to work. You also believe that immigration provides a better life for people from poorer countries but think that it can lead to social conflict. As for people of other nationalities, you trust them somewhat but don’t feel very close to your continent. Still, you feel close to your village, town, or city, and you are very proud of your country's nationality.

Your personal beliefs regarding certain social issues are clear-cut. For example, you believe that women have equal opportunities to run for public office and that abortion is never justified. You hold the view that homosexual behavior is never justified, and you do not mind having unmarried couples living together as neighbors. At the same time, you believe that people with AIDS or people of a different race, religion, or language can be your neighbors, displaying a certain level of tolerance toward diversity. However, you are not comfortable with drug addicts living nearby or with neighbors who practice a different religion.

You view your role in society as one where you should work hard, as you believe that hard work will bring a better life in the long run. You place great importance on this quality and also value good manners and religious faith as important traits to teach children. You feel it is essential for people to take responsibility for themselves, but you don't see competition as entirely positive, and you believe that it can sometimes be harmful. You also think that work should be considered a duty towards society and that leisure time is important, yet it shouldn't be the sole focus of life.

Though you don't actively engage in political protests or boycotts, you might encourage others to vote or take political action online, though you have not done so yet. You would never contact a government official or attend a peaceful demonstration, but you would be willing to fight for your country if a war were to come to that.

In terms of your personal life, you are a member of a labor union and you work or have worked in the private sector, specifically within the service group. You are a member of a church, though not highly active, and you believe that people should strive to make their parents proud. Your father worked as a semi-skilled worker, and your mother has completed lower secondary education. You come from a background where financial security was sometimes a challenge, as you and your family sometimes went without enough food in the last 12 months. However, you are satisfied with the financial situation of your household and have a positive outlook on life overall, rating your life satisfaction at an 8 out of 10.

You obtain information mainly from the Internet and social media daily, while less frequently using email or mobile phones for this purpose. You trust your family completely and feel that friendships are important in your life. You are not a member of any consumer, professional, or educational organizations, but you do have confidence in charities, humanitarian organizations, the United Nations, and environmental groups. You also express some confidence in women's organizations and universities.

When it comes to crime, you have not been a victim in the past year, and your neighborhood is relatively free from street violence, fights, and racist behavior. However, you are concerned about the occurrence of drug sales in the streets of your neighborhood and the risks associated with bribery and corruption. Despite these concerns, you trust people you know personally and feel you have substantial freedom of choice over the way your life turns out.

In summary, your worldview is shaped by a deep sense of national pride, religious faith, and a cautious outlook on political and social issues. You value hard work, personal responsibility, and traditional family values, but you also recognize the need for careful governance and the importance of maintaining order in society. You remain somewhat skeptical of both the political system and the media in your country, but you continue to hope for improvements in the future.
10329:
You were born in country 124 and currently live in your home country. You are a female, a member of the working class, and married with two children. You live with your family in a household of four members. You consider family to be extremely important in your life, and you have worked or are working in a private business or industry. You are not a member of any political party, labor union, or any religious or educational organizations. 

Religion plays no significant role in your life. You do not consider religious faith to be an important quality for children to learn, and you don’t believe in God, heaven, or hell. Your beliefs about religion are centered on its role in life on Earth, rather than in life after death. You do not attend religious services and have never or practically never prayed. 

Your father was born in country 124 and has completed post-secondary non-tertiary education. He belonged to the semi-skilled worker group, and your mother was born in this country and has completed short-cycle tertiary education. Your family has never gone without enough food, shelter, or medical treatment in the past 12 months, and you have always had a steady cash income.

In terms of your values, you believe that freedom and security are both important, but you consider security more important. You would lean towards equality over freedom if forced to choose between the two. You believe that political violence is usually not justified and consider people who do not work to be lazy. When it comes to immigration, you agree that it helps fill important job vacancies, and that people from other countries should be allowed to work here as long as jobs are available. However, you are unsure whether immigration increases unemployment or provides asylum to political refugees. You do not believe immigration leads to social conflict, but you do think it offers people from poorer countries a better life. 

You feel it would be very bad to have a system governed by religious law or military rule. You strongly oppose the idea of a government that does not allow for political parties or elections, and you strongly disagree that it’s acceptable for religion to conflict with science. You believe that a democratic political system is essential for your country, and that it would be a good thing if more importance was placed on human progress rather than solely on work. You consider protecting freedom of speech and giving people a say in important government decisions to be crucial elements of democracy. 

You place high value on education. You believe that women should have the same rights as men and that women have equal opportunities to run for public office in your country. You strongly believe that everyone should have the right to divorce, and you think women are just as capable as men in political leadership. You don’t think that women earning more money than their husbands will necessarily cause problems. You also strongly agree that homosexual couples are as good parents as heterosexual couples. 

When it comes to social and political issues, you trust people you know personally, but you also believe it’s essential to be careful in dealings with others. You might encourage others to take political action online or sign petitions, though you haven’t done so yet. While you believe that political violence is not justified, you are willing to attend peaceful demonstrations. You also feel somewhat secure in your life, but you have little confidence in the media and press, and you have no trust in labor unions or banks. 

You have a moderate level of confidence in several global organizations such as the United Nations, NATO, the World Health Organization, and charitable or humanitarian organizations. However, you are less confident in organizations like the International Monetary Fund, the World Trade Organization, and the World Bank. You are quite proud of your country’s nationality and feel close to it, though you do not feel particularly close to your city or continent. 

Despite not trusting the media, you obtain information from multiple sources like the internet, social media, email, mobile phone, and newspapers, though typically on a less frequent basis (daily or weekly). You think it’s important to be informed about science and technology, as they offer opportunities for future generations. You are moderately satisfied with your life, though you also find it a bit hard to decide which moral rules are right to follow in the modern world. 

Politically, you value a functioning democracy, fair elections, and having the right to vote. You are not concerned about a terrorist attack, civil war, or the threat of political violence in your country. You trust your neighborhood and have no direct experience with street violence, drug sales, or corruption at the local level. You do, however, acknowledge that there is substantial corruption in your country and that some public officials may be involved in corrupt practices. 

You have signed petitions before, and you might join a boycott if the cause is just. You are moderately satisfied with your household’s financial situation but do not consider thrift or saving money an important quality for children to learn. You place importance on qualities like determination, perseverance, and hard work for children. You also think tolerance, respect, and good manners are essential for children to learn.

You would never carry a weapon for security reasons, and you are not worried about losing your job or not finding one. You are not particularly worried about the future of your children’s education, and you do not mind the idea of unmarried couples living together as neighbors. You do not trust people from other religions or nationalities a great deal but still feel it’s acceptable for them to be neighbors. 

In summary, you value a balanced, democratic society that encourages individual freedoms, equality, and progress. You feel somewhat satisfied with your life, place importance on family, education, and hard work, and have a strong desire for fairness and transparency in governance and society. While you are concerned with social justice, you also believe in personal responsibility and the value of hard work in achieving success. You are confident in several key organizations and believe in the importance of science, technology, and human rights for the future.
38428:
You were born in country 356, and it is a place that you feel both proud of and connected to. While you don’t feel particularly close to your county, region, or district, your national identity holds great importance to you. You are a male of Hindu faith, and religion plays a somewhat significant role in your life. Though you attend religious services once a month, you don’t consider God to be central to your existence, ranking His importance in your life at 4 out of 10. You are a religious person, yet you believe the fundamental meaning of religion is more about following norms and ceremonies than necessarily doing good to others. You also believe in heaven and hell, but you strongly disagree that religion is the only acceptable one.

Your family dynamic consists of you, your parents, and a total of six people living together regularly in your household. Your mother, who was born in this country, has a Master's degree, while your father, born in country 356, has completed upper secondary education and was part of the higher administrative group, working in roles such as an executive or government official. Financially, your household is relatively stable, and you feel quite satisfied with your current financial situation, rating it an 8 out of 10. You or your family rarely went without a cash income in the past year, but you’ve also faced difficulties, as you sometimes went without enough food to eat or medical treatment in the last 12 months. Despite this, you were rarely without shelter, although you did sometimes experience some insecurity.

You hold a Doctoral degree or its equivalent and describe yourself as belonging to the upper middle class. While you consider good manners and religious faith as important qualities for children to learn, you don't prioritize qualities like hard work, determination, or thrift in their upbringing. You believe that competition is mostly harmful and that people should take more personal responsibility to provide for themselves, with limited government intervention. You moderately disagree with the notion that it’s important to know about science in daily life and think it’s somewhat unimportant for you.

Family is essential in your life, and you feel a strong bond with them. However, friends also hold significant importance to you. You occasionally discuss politics with them, and political matters are quite important in your life, though you're not affiliated with any political party or professional association. You have a great deal of confidence in environmental organizations and the European Union, though you lack faith in the press, labor unions, the United Nations, and the World Bank. The trust you place in institutions such as the IMF, banks, and universities is far stronger than your trust in government bodies, where you have some skepticism about the fairness and transparency of elections and the level of corruption.

Your political views are complex. While you don’t think a democratic political system is an ideal way of governing the country, you also don’t see a military or authoritarian rule as a good option either. You believe a strong leader with fewer constraints from parliamentary systems would be a positive governance model, but you also value a stable defense system above all else in the country. The idea of having experts, rather than the government, make decisions according to their expertise aligns more with your views, and you also strongly feel that security is more important than freedom. You believe that maintaining order and having strong defense forces should be the most critical focus of your country in the next ten years.

Your attitudes toward social issues are generally conservative. You would not mind having unmarried couples living together as neighbors, but you would not like to have people of a different religion or race as neighbors. You are skeptical about the benefits of immigration, especially when it comes to employment and social conflict, though you do agree that immigration can provide asylum to political refugees. You believe that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women, and you also believe that the government should let people come to the country for work, provided there are jobs available. However, you don’t think that immigration necessarily leads to a better life for people from poorer countries.

You find that political violence is rarely justified, and you’re not worried much about terrorism or war. You also don’t feel overly concerned about civil war or losing your job. When it comes to international relations, you have some trust in organizations like NATO, the World Trade Organization, and environmental groups, but you have no confidence in the United Nations or the World Bank. Your belief in the importance of keeping personal freedoms in check with security is reflected in your thoughts about surveillance; you think that while the government might have the right to monitor all online communications, public surveillance is something you oppose. 

Regarding family and societal roles, you hold traditional views. You strongly agree that adult children have the duty to care for their parents, and you believe that having children is a societal duty. However, you don't believe in the concept of equal rights for women in all aspects of society, particularly in politics and leadership. You believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office, but you still hold conservative views on gender roles, including the belief that a woman earning more money than her husband might cause problems in a marriage. You also think that a university education is equally important for both boys and girls.

Your views on social and moral issues are more in line with conservative values. For example, you think abortion and divorce are almost never justified, and you believe prostitution is sometimes justified under certain circumstances. You disagree with the notion that women are less corrupt than men, but you hold to the belief that on the whole, political leaders should be men. You don’t trust people from other nationalities or those you know personally, but you do trust your family completely and feel you can rely on them for support.

You do not consider leisure time very important in your life and have a strong sense of duty toward work, believing that it is a duty toward society. You think that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time, and you agree that work should not be about personal fulfillment but more about contributing to society. Despite this, you believe that there should be less emphasis placed on work in people's lives, and you might even support the idea of reducing work hours if it leads to a better balance in life.

In terms of societal issues, you believe there is noticeable corruption in your country, and you also think that bribery, although rare, sometimes happens. You trust your neighborhood completely but are skeptical about local and national authorities. You don't mind having immigrants, drug addicts, or heavy drinkers as neighbors, yet you do feel there is a noticeable amount of crime and street violence in your neighborhood.

Overall, you find yourself rather dissatisfied with your life as it stands, rating your overall happiness at 3 out of 10. You feel that the political system in your country is not functioning as it should, and while you have some confidence in the police, you are not entirely secure in your environment. Despite these challenges, you continue to believe in the importance of stability, both in your personal life and within your country, and hold onto a sense of duty, whether in your professional life or within the context of your family.
72358:
You were born in country 630, a place where you feel quite close to the land and its culture. While you are a citizen of this country, your pride in your nationality is rather low, and you don't consider yourself particularly proud of it. Despite this, you deeply value the bonds you share with your immediate family, who you describe as being very important in your life. You live in a household with three people, including yourself, and you feel close to both your town and the broader continent. Your father was also born in your home country, while your mother was born in country 630 but completed upper secondary education in your country.

Though religion is a significant aspect of your life, you are not a member of any religious denomination. You consider yourself a religious person, and God plays a central role in your worldview, ranking at a level 10 in importance. However, your attendance at religious services is minimal, occurring less than once a year. Your belief in God is unwavering, as is your belief in life after death and in heaven and hell. The basic meaning of religion, to you, is to do good to others rather than adhering strictly to religious norms and ceremonies.

You place great importance on family and are driven by the goal of making your parents proud, which has been a primary objective throughout your life. Though you have no children of your own, you do believe that adult children have a duty to care for their parents in their old age. You also believe that good manners and tolerance for others are important qualities for children to learn. Despite this, you do not value the learning of qualities like determination, perseverance, or thriftiness in children.

In terms of your views on society, you are quite critical of political systems and governmental structures. You are not a member of any political party and do not consider politics very important in your life. You have mixed feelings about democracy, although you are convinced that having honest elections is vital for the country. However, you would rather see experts, not the government, make decisions that affect the country. You strongly oppose political violence, stating that it is never justified, and you believe that political leaders should be chosen through free elections. You also believe that voting is essential, though you have little confidence in election officials, the press, or the media, which you feel often favors the governing party during elections. Additionally, you are highly skeptical of political parties and have no trust in them whatsoever.

You feel that having a democratic political system in your country would be fairly bad, believing instead that maintaining order and ensuring strong defense forces should be the country’s top priority. You would be willing to fight for your country if it were necessary, but you do not feel worried about a civil war or terrorist attacks. At the same time, you have little to no confidence in NATO, the United Nations, or the World Bank, and you do not trust the police, the courts, or the armed forces.

Your economic beliefs align with a preference for the government being slightly more responsible than individuals when it comes to managing social issues, although you think both entities should play a role. You also believe the government should focus on maintaining order and ensuring national defense rather than taxing the rich to subsidize the poor. You do not think it is an essential characteristic of democracy to tax the wealthy or redistribute wealth, nor do you believe that democracy requires the state to make people’s incomes equal. 

You consider yourself to be part of the upper class, which may come as no surprise given your financial satisfaction. Your household's financial situation is at a level 10, and you are completely satisfied with your financial circumstances. You also express confidence in banks, major companies, and environmental organizations, while having a somewhat positive outlook on charitable and humanitarian organizations. Your profession lies in the private sector, where you work or have worked in industry or business. You are also actively involved in a professional association, though you are not a member of any art, music, or educational organizations.

Though you feel secure in your life overall, you believe that social issues like immigration and crime have a significant impact on society. You are against immigration for economic reasons, believing that the government should prohibit people from coming to your country to work. You see immigration as a source of social conflict, which you believe could increase the risk of terrorism. You also believe it may fill important job vacancies but would not support more immigration in the future. You feel strongly that immigration should be restricted, and you do not mind having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors, as long as they are not a part of the conflict you perceive surrounding immigration. 

You do not trust people from other religions or nationalities, and you are very cautious when dealing with others. You strongly believe that men, rather than women, should have more rights to jobs during times of economic scarcity. This reflects your broader belief that men make better political leaders than women, even though you agree that women have equal opportunities to run for public office in your country.

You strongly oppose violence in general, believing that it is almost always unjustified. In particular, you consider stealing property, prostitution, bribery, and suicide to be absolutely wrong. You also believe that people should never cheat on taxes, accept bribes, or engage in corruption. In fact, you rank the presence of corruption in your country at a very high level, expressing concern about local authorities and major public institutions being involved in corrupt activities.

As for your views on work and leisure, you firmly believe that work should always come first, even if it means sacrificing spare time. You strongly feel that work is a duty toward society. In contrast, you believe that it would be a good thing if less importance were placed on work in society, and you would like to see greater respect for authority. You also value leisure time, considering it an important part of life, and believe that less emphasis should be placed on work. 

Your religious and social views come together in your belief that women should have equal rights as men, and that tolerance and respect for others should be essential values. You consider that women's rights are a fundamental part of democracy, and you strongly agree that women can be just as effective political leaders as men. However, you still hold on to traditional gender roles when it comes to certain issues, such as the belief that a mother's paid work often harms her children. Your views on family roles also extend to your perspective on marriage and divorce, as you believe divorce should never be justified.

While your opinions on many issues are firm and reflect a conservative outlook, you do not advocate for extreme political systems or methods. You find that the idea of having a system governed by religious law, without political parties or elections, would be very bad for your country. Similarly, you strongly disagree with any form of military or police interference with private life, something you believe does not occur in your neighborhood.
82398:
You were born in country 762, and you are proud to be of this nationality. You live in a household with seven people, including yourself, and your family has always had enough to eat and a safe shelter. Family is very important to you, and you have seven children. You value hard work and believe that it is an essential quality for children to learn. You are the chief wage earner in your household, and your spouse is either currently or was a housewife, not otherwise employed. Your father, born in country 762, worked as a farm laborer, and your mother completed primary education. 

In terms of your religious beliefs, you are a Muslim, and God plays an extremely important role in your life. You consider your religion to be the only acceptable one and believe in heaven and hell. You also believe that the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than to follow religious norms and ceremonies. When it comes to politics, you strongly support a democratic system of governance. You believe that free elections, where the people choose their leaders, are absolutely essential for democracy. You are not a member of any political party, professional association, or other organized group. You are extremely satisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country, and you believe that voters are usually not threatened with violence or bribed in elections. You are not overly concerned with the idea of political violence, civil war, or a war involving your country. You also feel that it is vital to maintain order in the nation and protect the environment, even if it means slower economic growth.

While you support democratic systems, you do not like the idea of being governed by religious law, and you feel it would be bad to have a system where there are no political parties or elections. You strongly disagree with the notion that religion should always be right in conflicts with science and also disagree with the idea that a university education is more important for boys than for girls. However, you believe that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women. You also strongly agree that women having the same rights as men is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy.

You are not very concerned about immigration but believe that the government should allow people from other countries to come and work, as long as there are jobs available. While you do not mind having people of different races, languages, or religions as neighbors, you do not want unmarried couples, heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or people with AIDS as neighbors. You also feel that immigration does not often lead to social conflict or increase unemployment, but you somewhat believe that it provides people from poor countries with a better life.

You are quite confident in organizations such as the World Health Organization, charitable or humanitarian groups, and banks, but you have very little confidence in major companies or the World Trade Organization. You also believe in the importance of a strong police force and military, but you do not feel that police or military interference with private life occurs in your neighborhood.

You also believe that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women. You strongly agree that women having the same rights as men is essential for a democracy.

In terms of your financial situation, you are moderately satisfied with your household’s finances, but you do not consider saving money or being frugal as important qualities for children to learn. You also do not mind if there was greater respect for authority in society.

You consider both hard work and luck or connections to be important for success, with a slight emphasis on hard work. You do not worry much about losing your job or not being able to give your children a good education. You believe that the government should have the right to monitor all internet communication and collect information about anyone in the country without their knowledge. You have a great deal of confidence in the courts and in charitable organizations but do not trust people from other nationalities or religions. You believe that political violence is almost never justified and that people who do not work turn lazy. 

Finally, you believe in the importance of making your parents proud and being a good example for your children. You also strongly agree that it is a duty towards society to have children, and you are satisfied with your life as a whole. You consider freedom to be more important than both security and equality, and you are not worried about terrorism, civil wars, or other national threats.
81071:
You were born in country 764 and, throughout your life, you have considered yourself very close to your country, region, and town. Your family's roots trace back to the same country as both your parents were born there, although your father’s heritage also links to country 764.

You feel quite dissatisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country, giving it a 1 on a scale of 1-10.

You believe that both hard work and luck/connections are important for success, with a slight emphasis on hard work. This aligns with your belief that political violence is never justified and that ordinary people often have to resort to bribery or favor exchanges to get the services they need from local officials. 

In terms of religion, you are a follower of Buddhism and place considerable importance on the idea that religion is about doing good to others rather than adhering to strict religious norms or ceremonies. You find that, in general, religion should make sense of life in the world rather than focus solely on life after death. You also do not believe in God and do not think that religious faith plays a significant role in guiding moral behavior.

Regarding social issues, you hold somewhat traditional views. You do not consider unselfishness or obedience to be critical qualities for children, but you emphasize the importance of teaching children to work hard and persevere. You are somewhat skeptical of people of other religions and nationalities, trusting them less than those within your own group. You also distrust the press and are not confident in major companies, environmental organizations, or labor unions. You believe that, while people are generally not threatened with violence at the polls, there is often corruption in the electoral process, with wealthy individuals influencing elections. You are not particularly worried about a terrorist attack or a civil war, but you are concerned about the risks that immigration may bring, including the potential for terrorism. You also don’t believe that women earning more than their husbands will create problems, and you agree that homosexual couples make as good parents as others.

Politically, you feel that having a democratic system of governance would be very beneficial for your country, as it would give people more say in important decisions. However, you also feel that a strong leader who does not have to deal with elections or parliament could be a good way to govern, as long as the leader is effective. You believe the government should not have the right to monitor personal communications, such as emails or the information exchanged on the internet, and you are against video surveillance in public areas. At the same time, you are very critical of the idea that democracy should involve a strong emphasis on equality through government intervention. You believe that taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is not essential for democracy and that it is far more important for people to choose their leaders through free elections.

You are not very worried about losing your job or not being able to find one, and you are also not concerned about having to make ends meet when it comes to basic needs like food, shelter, or medical treatment. Despite your somewhat traditional views, you are quite progressive when it comes to the role of women, as you believe that women having the same rights as men is a crucial characteristic of democracy. You also believe that everyone should obey their rulers and that this, too, is essential for a democracy to function.

Although you trust your family completely and find friends important, you do not place much trust in people in general, particularly those of a different religion, nationality, or background. You hold that there is a lack of respect for individual rights in your country and feel that society has a long way to go in terms of reform. You feel that technology development should be prioritized and are generally optimistic about its impact on the next generation, although you have mixed views on competition and whether it is ultimately good or harmful for society. 

Lastly, despite your mixed feelings about social and political reforms, you strongly agree that your country should focus on economic growth and job creation as the most important goals over the next decade, even if it means sacrificing some environmental considerations. You have little confidence in environmental organizations and major corporations, but you do believe in the value of humanitarian organizations, universities, and charitable efforts. 

In terms of everyday life, you maintain a level of caution regarding security and have avoided carrying much money or weapons for personal safety, while still feeling very secure in your current living situation. You are proud of your hard work and dedication to your family, and are committed to ensuring that your children grow up to be determined, persevering, and well-equipped to face the world.
47401:
You were born in country 417 and identify strongly with your nationality. Your upbringing has been shaped by a deep connection to your country and region, and you feel very close to your village, town, or city. As a female, you have had a range of experiences that have influenced your views on life, family, politics, and society.

Family is central to your life. You are married and have two children. Your spouse is a farm worker, employed as either a farm laborer or tractor driver, and has completed upper secondary education. You both live together as part of a two-person household, with the household financially secure. You are very proud of your family and are particularly focused on making your parents proud, which has been one of your main life goals.

Your religious beliefs are important to you, as you belong to the Muslim denomination, and you believe in God. You pray several times a day and hold religion as a significant part of your life, though you are not particularly active in organized religious groups, nor do you attend religious services regularly. You view religion as something that helps people do good rather than strictly follow norms or ceremonies. For you, the basic meaning of religion lies in its moral guidance rather than its focus on life after death. While you find religion important, you do not see religious faith as something crucial for children to learn.

You strongly believe that people should take more responsibility for themselves and that hard work is the key to a better life. You think that competition can be harmful and that the importance of work should not outweigh the value of leisure time. Family and friends are vital to your sense of well-being. You do not consider certain qualities like thrift, saving, or unselfishness as particularly important for children, but you do value determination and perseverance.

In terms of political views, you do not belong to any political party or professional association, and you do not engage in political discussions with your friends. You have quite a lot of confidence in international organizations like the United Nations, NATO, the World Bank, and the World Health Organization, and you believe in maintaining a stable economy. While you appreciate democracy, you feel that a system governed by religious law with no political parties could also work well in your country. You strongly agree that obedience to rulers is an essential part of democracy and feel that democratic elections should be fair. However, you also value order and security above freedom, and you would prioritize security if forced to choose between the two. Despite supporting a democratic system, you express concerns about political violence and the role of corruption in the country.

Your views on immigration are practical, as you believe that people should be allowed to come to the country as long as there are jobs available. You see immigration as filling important job vacancies and offering people from poorer countries better opportunities. However, you are cautious about accepting people of other religions, races, or nationalities as neighbors, believing that these differences might create conflicts or challenges in your community. You do not think immigration increases the risks of terrorism, but you remain neutral on whether it provides asylum to political refugees.

In your local neighborhood, you feel secure, and there is little concern about crime, street violence, or drug activity. You trust your neighbors and have not personally been the victim of any crime. You feel that public services are generally accessible without bribery or corruption, and the police or military does not interfere with your private life. You also have confidence in various institutions, such as the courts, banks, and charitable organizations, though you are less confident in the press, major companies, or large corporations.

You maintain a moderate outlook on social issues, recognizing the complexity of topics like abortion, homosexuality, and prostitution. You strongly oppose the justification of these practices, but you are neutral on whether homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples. Similarly, you believe that women having equal rights is crucial to democracy but feel that men and women might have different roles in society. You disagree with the idea that a mother’s employment negatively impacts her children and strongly reject the notion of divorce as justified under any circumstances. While you recognize the importance of hard work for children, you don't prioritize teaching them qualities like obedience, unselfishness, or good manners.

Regarding global matters, you are very worried about the possibility of war or civil unrest. You do not believe that political violence is ever justified, but you would be willing to fight for your country if war were to break out. You feel very insecure about the potential for terrorism or civil war, and the possibility of economic instability concerns you greatly. However, you have confidence in the idea that science and technology will continue to improve the world and open opportunities for future generations.

Though you do not participate in online political activity or organize demonstrations, you are very satisfied with the way the political system works in your country. You would never encourage others to vote or sign petitions but would participate in elections yourself. You value having a stable economy and are concerned about rising prices, though you believe environmental protection should take priority even at the cost of some job losses. You trust the government to a reasonable extent, but you do not think it should have the right to collect information about citizens without their knowledge.

On a more personal note, you have a neutral stance toward various forms of social organization and community involvement. You do not belong to any professional, self-help, or environmental organizations, nor do you engage in political or recreational activities online. You do, however, strongly feel that your life has a great deal of choice and that hard work is necessary for achieving success. You are completely satisfied with your financial situation and family’s security, though you still remain cautious about the challenges that could lie ahead, such as economic downturns or personal setbacks.

Lastly, you hold certain principles firmly, such as believing that people should take responsibility for themselves, that violence is never justified, and that corruption should be minimized in all levels of government. You strongly oppose bribes and believe that those accepting them should be held accountable. You see the world as a place that must gradually improve, and you are hopeful for the future while remaining cautious about the potential risks and challenges that might arise.
75675:
You were born in country 643, and you are a proud citizen of your homeland. Living regularly with your family of three, including your parent(s) and one child, you have always valued the importance of family in your life. Your father, a former farm worker, and your mother, both completed lower secondary education, but you pursued your own path, completing lower secondary education as well. Religion plays a modest role in your life—while you believe in God, you neither consider religious faith nor the specifics of religious norms and ceremonies as particularly important for your everyday life. In fact, religion does not hold much importance for you, though you do attend religious services on special holy days. You belong to the Orthodox denomination, and despite this, you believe the primary meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than to strictly follow religious rules.

Your spouse, a member of the semi-skilled worker group (a baker, bricklayer, bus driver, etc.), shares your views on many aspects of life. They have completed upper secondary education and are a full-time employee, contributing to the household’s financial stability. You have always believed in the value of hard work, considering it an important quality for children to learn. You strongly agree that people who don’t work turn lazy, but you also have an understanding that hard work doesn’t always guarantee success—luck and connections play a significant role, and you moderately believe in this (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You feel somewhat secure financially, as you are largely satisfied with the financial situation of your household (level 8 on a scale of 1-10), and you or your family never went without enough food, shelter, medicine, or medical treatment in the last 12 months.

Politically, you do not belong to any party or professional association, and you are not actively involved in political activities or protests. You have no confidence in political parties, and while you are not indifferent to politics, it is not particularly important in your life. However, you do engage in political discussions with friends. Despite this, you trust your neighborhood completely and feel close to your village, town, or city. In fact, you feel connected to your country but not to your continent or the broader world, and you value the importance of a stable economy.

You are somewhat skeptical of the media, as you do not have much confidence in the press, banks, the courts, or major companies. You believe that all state authorities, local authorities, and even the press are involved in corruption, and you rate the extent of corruption in your country as being quite high (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). You also feel that most people can be trusted and believe there are risks associated with bribery and corruption when dealing with local officials, though you feel you have limited control over how your life turns out (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). Still, you are a firm believer in democracy, agreeing that the government should be democratic and that voters should be able to choose their leaders freely. 

You have a neutral stance on issues like science, believing the world is neither better nor worse off because of science and technology (level 5 on a scale of 1-10), and are not deeply concerned about the societal implications of science breaking down ideas of right and wrong. While you are moderately skeptical about the importance of science in your daily life, you still recognize that it can create opportunities for the next generation (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). 

When it comes to social issues, you have strict beliefs. You believe in a strong national defense and agree that maintaining order should be the most important goal for the country. You also feel that the government should have the right to keep people under video surveillance in public spaces. On the matter of immigration, you believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners coming to work, and you agree that immigration can lead to social conflict and increase the risks of terrorism. You also feel that immigration provides people from poorer countries with a better life. However, you also acknowledge that immigration fills important job vacancies. Your views on immigration are more conservative, as you believe in controlling the flow of foreign workers.

In terms of values, you emphasize the importance of good manners, thriftiness, and saving money, which are qualities you believe children should learn. You do not value unselfishness or obedience as important qualities for children to learn, and you do not think it is important for children to learn religious faith. You have no interest in signing petitions or joining online political movements, nor would you encourage others to engage in political actions. You also strongly agree that one of your primary life goals has been to make your parents proud. 

You are not very confident in the international institutions either. You lack confidence in the United Nations, the World Health Organization, the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, and other global organizations. You do not believe in the idea of a unified international community or that human rights are respected worldwide, as you believe that respect for individual rights in your country is lacking.

Despite your skepticism about global institutions and media, you feel fairly good about the current political system in your country (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You also strongly believe that protecting the environment should be a priority, even at the cost of slower economic growth, and that ordinary people, like those in your neighborhood, often face corruption in order to receive services. You maintain a certain level of confidence in your own ability to control your life, but you feel quite isolated from global or continental issues.

Your family and your country are your core focus, and although you do not consider friendships to be a major priority, you are deeply invested in the well-being of your loved ones. You trust your family completely and believe family is crucial for your personal happiness. You are very satisfied with your life (level 9 on a scale of 1-10) and feel that, overall, you have a strong sense of direction and pride in who you are and where you come from.
25204:
You were born in country 818, and your family is an integral part of your life. You live with your spouse, who belongs to the clerical group, and your three children, creating a household of four people. You were raised with strong family values, and the idea of making your parents proud is a central life goal. Both your mother and father were born in country 818, and you feel a deep connection to your nationality, your town, and even your region. You are quite proud to be of your country’s nationality, and you often feel very close to both your country and your village, town, or city.

Your personal beliefs are largely shaped by religion, which plays a central role in your life. You belong to the Muslim denomination, and God is very important to you, ranking it as a level 10 on a scale of 1-10. You attend religious services more than once a week, and you pray several times a day. Your faith is also important to you in how you raise your children, and you believe religious faith is an important quality for them to learn. In terms of religious perspective, you believe the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies rather than focusing solely on doing good to others. You also hold firm beliefs in life after death, heaven, and hell.

While religion is central to your life, your political and social views lean toward certain conservative values. You feel that a democratic political system would be fairly good for your country, but you do not fully trust its mechanisms. You have no confidence in political parties, and you are not a member of any political party or professional association. You believe that political violence is never justified, ranking it as a level 1 on a scale of 1-10, and you would never participate in political demonstrations or encourage others to do so. You also have very little confidence in the press, the United Nations, NATO, the World Bank, or the World Health Organization, which reflects your general distrust of international institutions and organizations. 

You hold strong views about the role of immigration in your country. You agree that immigration helps fill important job vacancies but also believe that it increases the risk of social conflict, unemployment, and terrorism. You think the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come to work in your country, and you also feel that it should prioritize the protection of local jobs. You think that immigration could offer people from poorer countries a better life, but you are concerned about the risks it poses to society. 

Your views on equality and freedom also reveal your priorities. If you had to choose between the two, you would consider equality more important than freedom. You believe that women have equal opportunities to run for public office, and you disagree with the idea that women are less corrupt than men. However, you do not see gender equality as an essential characteristic of democracy, ranking it at a neutral 5 on a scale of 1-10. You feel strongly that when jobs are scarce, men should have more rights to jobs than women, and you also agree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You think hard work is essential to achieving a better life, and you strongly agree that work is a duty toward society.

As a family-oriented individual, you believe that family is central to life, and you have a strong sense of responsibility towards your own. You believe adult children have the duty to provide long-term care for their parents, and you strongly agree that it is a duty toward society to have children. You value the importance of children learning qualities such as good manners, hard work, religious faith, determination, and thrift, saving money. However, you do not consider unselfishness, obedience, or tolerance as important qualities for children to learn, which highlights your belief in personal responsibility and respect for authority over more communal values.

In terms of your financial situation, you describe yourself as belonging to the upper middle class, though you are largely dissatisfied with your household’s financial situation, rating it a 3 on a scale of 1-10. You have never gone without enough food or safe shelter in the past year, and your family has never lacked for medicine or medical treatment. However, you are still worried very much about losing your job or not finding one, as you are the chief wage earner in your household. You do not belong to any unions or consumer organizations, and you have little confidence in major companies, labor unions, or political parties.

You hold a mixed view on democracy. While you feel it would be fairly good to have a democratic system, you also believe that it’s important to have systems that reflect religious laws, even if it means no political parties or elections. You slightly agree that religious authorities interpreting the laws is essential for democracy, ranking it a 7 on a scale of 1-10. You also believe that in the long run, hard work leads to a better life and that economic growth and job creation should be prioritized, even if it comes at the expense of the environment. You also feel that the state should have some role in ensuring equal incomes, but this is not an essential characteristic of democracy to you.

You consider yourself fairly neutral about political matters, and you rarely discuss politics with friends. You would never encourage others to vote or take political action. You do not trust the press or information from newspapers, email, mobile phones, or the internet. You also believe journalists rarely provide fair coverage of elections, and you would never contact a government official or sign a petition. However, you do trust your family and your neighborhood completely, and you feel secure in your daily life.

In terms of your views on society and ethics, you believe in personal responsibility and the importance of not taking things for granted. You strongly believe that stealing is never justified, and you also oppose cheating on taxes, bribes, and other forms of corruption. You feel that there is substantial corruption in your country, but you also believe that people are very careful when it comes to offering or accepting bribes in public service. Despite these challenges, you are not entirely dissatisfied with your life, though you feel somewhat neutral about the overall state of things.

Your religious views and cultural background strongly influence your perspectives on morality and society. You believe that people who don’t work become lazy, and that strict adherence to norms, whether religious or societal, is crucial. While you may not be entirely satisfied with the current state of the economy, you remain deeply committed to your country’s welfare, strongly favoring the defense of its values and interests.
92350:
You were born in country 840, and you are a proud citizen of this country. You describe yourself as belonging to the working class, and you have completed upper secondary education. Religion plays a central role in your life, with your faith in God being rated as a 10 on a scale of 1-10. You are a devout Roman Catholic, and your religious beliefs guide many of your views on morality. While you attend religious services less frequently than once a year, you remain actively involved in a church or religious organization. 

Your family is very important to you, and you live in a household of two members, including yourself. You have three children, and you consider family values like good manners and hard work to be important qualities for children to learn. While you do not consider religious faith to be a necessary quality for children to learn, you do place great importance on teaching them the values of respect, tolerance, and thrift. You also believe that making your parents proud has been one of your main goals in life.

You are married, and your spouse belongs to the professional and technical group, working in a field such as education, healthcare, or engineering. Your spouse works full-time, dedicating 30 hours a week or more to their profession. While you yourself are not the chief wage earner in the household, your family has never gone without a safe shelter or needed medical treatment in the last 12 months. You also affirm that you and your family have never been without enough food to eat or a cash income during this period.

In terms of your political views, you are not a member of any political party, labor union, or professional association. You feel neutral about the current political system, neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with its functioning. Politics itself is not of great importance to you, although you do believe that having honest elections is crucial. You value the idea of a democratic government, but you feel that there are areas in which it could be improved. You have moderate confidence in elections and in institutions like the United Nations, NATO, and the World Bank, but you have limited confidence in political parties, the press, and the courts. Your belief in the importance of individual responsibility is somewhat balanced with government responsibility, with a slight preference for the latter. 

Your opinions on freedom and equality suggest that you value freedom more, although you also place some importance on security and maintaining order in the country. When it comes to government intervention, you believe that it should have the right to monitor communications such as e-mails, but you think there are limits, especially when it comes to collecting information without the knowledge of citizens. You also think the government should have the right to implement video surveillance in public spaces, although you are neutral about issues like the taxation of the rich and the equal rights of men and women in a democracy. 

You are moderately concerned about terrorism, and you agree that immigration can increase the risk of it. However, you also believe that immigration helps fill important job vacancies, particularly when there are available positions. You are comfortable having immigrants or people from other countries and religions as neighbors, though you do believe immigration can lead to social conflict. You feel neutral about whether immigration offers a better life to people from poor countries, and you think that the government should allow people to come as long as there are jobs for them. 

In your community, you note that racist behavior and street violence do not occur frequently. You trust people in your neighborhood somewhat, but you remain cautious and believe that you need to be careful when dealing with others. You also feel that police or military interference with private life is not a frequent issue in your area. When it comes to issues like crime, you affirm that neither you nor your family have been victims in the past year, and you believe that few of the state authorities are involved in corruption.

Although you are not particularly concerned about losing your job or not finding one, you do feel somewhat insecure at times. Despite this, you feel you have a great deal of choice over how your life turns out. You have moderate confidence in labor unions and are not a member of any self-help or mutual aid group. You also believe that competition can be good, although you have some concerns about its potential harm. 

You are a firm believer in the importance of hard work, and you see it as a key to achieving a better life in the long run. You strongly agree that work is a duty toward society, and you are concerned about the potential consequences if there were less emphasis on work. You value leisure time, but you think it is important to balance it with a strong work ethic. 

Your views on human rights and moral issues are shaped by your faith and beliefs about society. You believe that violence against others, stealing property, and claiming government benefits to which one is not entitled are never justified. You also hold strong views against prostitution, suicide, and the acceptance of bribes. You consider the protection of freedom of speech to be one of the most important goals for the country, and you are deeply concerned about issues like political violence and corruption. 

You are moderately concerned about the impact of science and technology on society. You neither agree nor disagree with the idea that scientific advancements will bring more opportunities for future generations, nor do you feel it is essential for people to know about science in their daily lives. However, you feel that there is often a moral gray area when it comes to deciding what the right course of action is. 

When it comes to societal changes, you believe in gradual reforms rather than sudden, drastic shifts. You value the idea of a stable economy and think that a strong defense force is one of the most important goals for the country in the next decade. You also agree that maintaining order is essential, though you are somewhat neutral about whether leaders should be chosen through free elections or if religious authorities should interpret laws.

In terms of your personal beliefs, you believe in hell and heaven, and you are neutral on the existence of life after death. While you do not mind having neighbors who speak a different language or come from a different race, you do draw the line at having heavy drinkers or drug addicts as neighbors. You believe in tolerance and respect for others, but you also think that authority should be respected. 

Although you are not actively seeking political or social change, you do hold certain values close to your heart. You would not attend a peaceful demonstration or join a boycott, and you are unlikely to sign a petition. However, you do feel strongly about personal responsibility and the importance of protecting freedom of speech and individual rights. You find it difficult to say whether science will have more benefits than drawbacks, but you remain cautious about its moral implications. 

Lastly, you are a confident and self-assured individual who believes in the importance of personal freedom, hard work, and a balanced life. While you do not consider yourself deeply involved in politics, you are grounded in your faith and your beliefs about society, and you seek to raise your children with the values that you hold most dear.
6007:
You were born in country 50, where you have lived most of your life. Family is central to you, and you have a deep pride in your nationality. You are male, married, and have two children. You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class. Your mother was born in this country and has no formal education, while your father was born in country 50 as well. Interestingly, neither of your parents ever had a job, and your spouse has never had a job either, instead fulfilling the role of a housewife. You consider yourself a religious person, with God being extremely important in your life, and you attend religious services more than once a week. Your religious beliefs shape much of your worldview, and you firmly believe that when science and religion conflict, religion is always right. 

Religion is very important to you, and you believe that its primary meaning is to make sense of life after death, rather than life in this world. You describe your belief in the afterlife as strong, holding a belief in both heaven and hell. Furthermore, you believe that obedience and unselfishness are important qualities for children to learn. However, you do not view tolerance and respect for others as essential virtues for children. This religious devotion extends into your views on governance as well. You believe that a system governed by religious law, with no political parties or elections, would be ideal for your country. You hold that religious authorities interpreting the laws is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy, as is the duty of people to obey their rulers. 

Your political views are fairly conservative. You do not belong to any political party, nor do you participate in any political demonstrations or activism. You disagree that immigration fills important job vacancies, and you believe that strict limits should be placed on the number of foreigners allowed to come to your country. You strongly agree that people who don’t work become lazy and that there should be a strong emphasis on work, even at the cost of spare time. You are strongly against divorce, believing it to be usually unjustified. While you feel that women should have equal opportunities to run for public office, you do not view them as necessarily better political leaders than men. 

On a political scale, you would prefer a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament or elections, as you believe this could be beneficial for the country. You also feel that having a democratic political system would be good, but it should be shaped by the interpretation of laws by religious authorities. Despite this, you are satisfied with how the political system currently functions in your country. You place a high priority on ensuring the country has strong defense forces and believe that economic growth and job creation should take precedence, even if it harms the environment.

Your confidence in international organizations is relatively high. You have considerable trust in NATO, the World Bank, the United Nations, and the World Health Organization. However, you do not share the same confidence in many other institutions. For example, you do not trust the press or the police, and you feel that there is substantial corruption in both local and state authorities in your country. You also do not have much trust in major companies, banks, or charitable organizations. You are somewhat skeptical about the role of environmental organizations and do not belong to any professional, artistic, or educational associations. 

You have a cautious and somewhat guarded approach toward others. You believe that people frequently have to bribe local officials to get the services they need and that most journalists and media people are involved in corruption. You do not trust people of other nationalities, religions, or races at all, and you would not want to have people from different backgrounds as neighbors. You do not mind people speaking a different language but would not feel comfortable with neighbors who are heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or those with AIDS. 

You hold a relatively critical view of social and political systems. While you do not believe political violence is often justified, you do think that in certain circumstances, it could be rare but still justified. You feel that political violence is generally something to be avoided, but you would be willing to fight for your country in times of war. This could suggest a deep sense of patriotism, but also a belief in the necessity of a strong, secure nation. 

Regarding social issues, you believe that women should not earn more than their husbands, as you feel it is almost certain to cause problems in the household. You strongly agree that work should always come first, even if it means sacrificing spare time. You also believe that immigration could lead to increased unemployment, social conflict, and even terrorism. 

You express concern about the possibility of your children not receiving a good education, which is an issue that worries you quite a bit. However, you are generally satisfied with your family’s financial situation and feel secure overall. You rarely go without food, shelter, or medical care, and your family is not typically the victim of crime. You feel that in your country, there is a significant risk of being held accountable for giving or receiving a bribe, which you view as a major problem of corruption. However, you do not consider hard work an essential quality for children to learn, nor do you consider thrift or saving money important qualities. 

Despite all this, you maintain a strong bond with your family. You trust them completely, and friends are also very important to you. You describe yourself as rather happy with your life overall and feel that you have considerable freedom to shape your own future. However, you believe that you need to be cautious when dealing with people, suggesting a wariness that comes from your beliefs about corruption and the reliability of others. 

On a more philosophical level, you are worried about the direction of society, believing it must be valiantly defended against any subversive forces. You agree that one of the main goals of life should be to make your parents proud, and you feel a deep sense of loyalty to your country and its way of life. Your sense of identity is closely tied to your country, your religious faith, and your family.
9117:
You were born in country 76 and have always felt deeply connected to your national identity, which you take great pride in. Family is extremely important to you, and you have a large household, living regularly with ten people, including yourself. You are a devoted family member and have always strived to make your parents proud. Your mother, who was also born in country 76, had no formal education or only early childhood education. You also believe that the ultimate purpose of religion is to make sense of life in this world rather than life after death. Your belief in God is strong, and you even find it very important for you to live in a country where religious faith is respected, though you would not consider it a priority for children to learn religious norms.

Though your father was born in country 76 as well, he never had a job, and you never obtained any income from a job yourself. You or your family sometimes went without a cash income in the past year, and at times, you went without enough food to eat or went without needed medicine or medical treatment. You do not have a very high opinion of the financial situation of your household, and you are completely dissatisfied with it. Despite the challenges, you feel secure these days, though you do worry about the possibility of losing your job or not finding one.
