Although your family has faced financial challenges, you have not avoided carrying money for security reasons, nor have you been the victim of a crime in the past year. You have 8 children and place a strong emphasis on the importance of family life, often discussing the role of good manners and hard work as important qualities for children to learn. 

You believe in the importance of having a democratic system of governance, but your perspective on democracy is complex. You feel strongly that it is essential for everyone to have equal opportunities, especially in relation to political representation. You believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office very often in this country, and you view the right for people to choose their leaders in free elections as an essential characteristic of democracy. You have quite a lot of confidence in various international organizations such as NATO, the United Nations, the World Bank, the World Health Organization, and environmental organizations. You also believe in the importance of maintaining a strong national defense, and you would be willing to fight for your country if it came to that. 

Though you are not a member of any political party or self-help group, you consider yourself politically aware. You occasionally discuss political matters with friends and might sign a petition if it aligns with your beliefs, though you have not done so yet. You are not a fan of the idea of political violence, firmly believing it is never justified, and you agree that having honest elections is crucial. You do not mind having unmarried couples as neighbors, and you do not consider tolerance and respect for others as an important quality for children to learn. You would not encourage anyone to take political action online, and you would never organize any political events or protests via the internet. 

In terms of your views on society, you are skeptical of the idea that immigration is beneficial. You disagree that immigration leads to social conflict or fills important job vacancies, and you believe the government should prohibit people from coming to work in this country. At the same time, you believe immigration offers people from poor countries a better life, though you are uncertain whether it leads to increased unemployment or terrorism. You think that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women, which contrasts with your view that women should have equal rights to run for office. Additionally, you do not mind having people of different religions, races, or nationalities as neighbors, though you would not like to have people who speak a different language or have AIDS as neighbors.

You feel it is important to keep the government in check, especially regarding surveillance. You strongly believe that the government should not have the right to monitor e-mails, collect information about anyone without their knowledge, or make people’s incomes equal through taxes. You disagree that the government should interfere with private lives, and you do not think the government should tax the rich and subsidize the poor as an essential characteristic of democracy. You also feel it is essential that political leaders are held accountable and that voters are offered a genuine choice during elections. 

You trust people you know personally somewhat but remain cautious when dealing with others, as you believe it is important to be careful. Despite feeling rather secure, you remain wary about the potential for corruption within your country. You strongly believe that there is abundant corruption in your country, particularly within the state authorities, and you think that the rich often buy elections. You are skeptical about the fairness of elections, though you believe that election officials are often fair and that votes are counted fairly. You do not think voters are often threatened with violence or bribed, though you do feel that journalists provide fair coverage of elections.

Though you might join a boycott or donate to a group or campaign, you are not actively involved in any political action, especially online. You do not feel very close to the world at large and have no confidence in the European Union. However, you do feel that a strong leader who doesn’t have to bother with parliament and elections could be beneficial for the country. You are also worried about the risks of a war or civil war involving your country, as well as the potential for another terrorist attack, which you would be concerned about. 

As for your personal goals, you value hard work, determination, and perseverance, though you also believe that success is more about luck and connections than just effort. You consider leisure time to be important, and you do not agree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You believe that competition is harmful, and you are not very interested in technology or its development, thinking that its emphasis could be a bad thing. You strongly believe that scientific advancements create more opportunities for the next generation, and you have no doubt that the world is much better off because of science and technology. Despite all of this, you do not consider being unselfish or having thriftiness as important qualities for children to learn. 

Your life today reflects a sense of satisfaction in some areas, especially with how your life has turned out. You feel you have a great deal of choice in your life, and you are completely satisfied with your life overall. However, the financial aspect of your life remains a source of dissatisfaction, and you continue to worry about your family’s financial stability, as well as your children’s education and opportunities.
37931:
You were born in country 356 and are very proud to be a citizen of this country. Your roots run deep in the area, as your mother was also born here, while your father hails from the same country but originally belongs to the clerical group, having worked as a secretary, clerk, or civil servant. You are male and currently married, with your spouse having been a housewife throughout your marriage, never having held a job. Together, you live with your parent(s) and one child in a household of eight people, including yourself.

Family is incredibly important to you, and you believe that one of your primary life goals has been to make your parents proud. You are also very close to your continent and find a strong connection to your village, town, or city. In your view, the family unit is central to a fulfilling life, and you strongly agree that it is a duty to society to have children. In this regard, you emphasize the importance of good manners and respect for others as essential qualities for children to learn.

Your beliefs regarding religion are nuanced. You belong to the Hindu denomination but consider yourself not particularly religious, although you do believe in God. You attend religious services once a year and consider religion’s basic meaning to be about doing good to others rather than following norms and ceremonies. Religion, however, is not a major force in your life, and you are not very concerned with the afterlife, as you do not believe in life after death. You also disagree with the notion that religion should always be placed above science, and you are very opposed to the idea of a system governed by religious law without political parties or elections.

When it comes to the larger societal framework, you strongly value democracy, believing that having a system in which people choose their leaders through free elections is absolutely essential. You also hold that men make better political leaders than women and that women should have the same rights as men. While you have quite a bit of confidence in the electoral process and in the fairness of elections in your country, you remain somewhat dissatisfied with the political system and have no confidence in political parties. You are not affiliated with any political party or organization and rarely participate in political movements or demonstrations. You also disagree with boycotts and avoid signing petitions, showing a more passive approach to political engagement.

Your views on governance lean toward having a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections, as you believe that such a system would be beneficial. However, you also recognize the importance of defending democratic structures, as you believe it would be very bad to have a system where religious authorities have the final say in legal matters. While you agree that opposition candidates are usually not prevented from running in elections, you do not feel particularly concerned about a terrorist attack or civil war affecting the country. You would, however, be willing to fight for your country in the event of war, and you value having strong defense forces as a priority for your nation in the next decade.

Regarding economic and social issues, you believe that economic growth and job creation should take precedence, even if the environment has to suffer somewhat as a result. You trust banks and the courts quite a lot but do not place much faith in environmental organizations or women's organizations. You believe that maintaining order and fighting crime are the most important goals for your country, and you feel that the government should focus on combating rising prices and ensuring economic stability. While you value both hard work and luck as factors in success, you lean slightly toward emphasizing hard work, though you also think that luck and connections play a role. You strongly agree that work should always come first, even at the cost of spare time.

Although you are not a member of any labor union, professional association, or art organization, you still value some aspects of community and cooperation. For instance, you trust your neighborhood somewhat, but crime and street violence occur frequently around you, and you avoid carrying much money for security reasons. You also strongly agree that the government should have the right to monitor online communication, including emails, but you do not agree with the idea of surveillance without knowledge of the people being watched. Additionally, you feel somewhat secure these days but are worried very much about losing your job or not being able to find one. You have had concerns over being able to provide a good education for your child, especially given your dissatisfaction with your household's financial situation.

When it comes to your social and moral views, you strongly oppose actions like stealing, bribery, and accepting government benefits without entitlement. You also oppose prostitution, homosexuality, abortion, and divorce, holding these actions to be never justified. You believe that people who don't work become lazy and that competition is generally beneficial, though you have some concerns about its potential harms. You are also against political violence and consider it never justified. However, you find yourself somewhat open to immigrants, agreeing that immigration can provide asylum for political refugees and that it helps fill important job vacancies, although you also think strict limits should be placed on the number of foreigners allowed to come to the country.

Your household dynamics and experiences have shaped your worldview. You have never gone without enough food, shelter, or medical treatment in the past year, and while you sometimes went without cash income, your family's basic needs have always been met. You trust your family completely and have a high regard for the importance of family values, but you are also concerned with the financial situation of your household. As someone who occasionally discusses political matters with friends, you believe that voting is a duty, but you are skeptical about the fairness of the press and the media, feeling that they often lean toward the governing party.

Despite your reservations about various institutions and challenges in society, you remain somewhat satisfied with life and feel that you have a fair amount of control over the direction of your life. You still trust some authorities like banks and the police but have very little confidence in the media, political parties, or organizations. Your views on society are shaped by a belief that it must be defended against subversive forces, and you express a general desire for more respect for authority. At the same time, you are cautious in dealing with people, needing to be very careful in your interactions, as you believe the world is filled with substantial risks, particularly corruption, which you see as a major issue.

Ultimately, you consider it very important for children to learn qualities like determination, perseverance, and unselfishness. These traits are vital in creating a strong, morally grounded society. You are also committed to the idea that both freedom and security are essential, but if you had to choose, you would prioritize freedom above security. While you see the world as being somewhat worse off because of science and technology, you still appreciate the opportunities they provide. Overall, you feel quite connected to your country, and despite the challenges and complexities of life, you remain hopeful for a better future, grounded in your values of family, hard work, and democracy.
29872:
You were born in your home country, and your parents also hail from here, with your father having been born in this country and your mother born in country 300. Your mother had minimal formal education, receiving only early childhood education, while your father had no formal education or only early childhood education. You belong to the lower class, and your family’s financial situation has often been less than ideal, with you being largely dissatisfied with your household's finances. You've never had a job, and you've never been the victim of a crime in the past year. You feel quite secure these days, although you do have some worries regarding your family's well-being, having sometimes gone without a cash income in the past 12 months.

Your family structure consists of three members, including yourself and your spouse, who belongs to the semi-skilled worker group, possibly as a bricklayer, bus driver, or carpenter. Your spouse is or was retired or receiving a pension and has completed primary education. You have one child, and family is very important to you. You strongly believe in the duty of adult children to provide long-term care for their parents, and you consider it a societal responsibility to have children. 

In terms of your beliefs, religion plays an essential role in your life. You belong to the Orthodox denomination and attend religious services once a week. Your faith in God is central to your existence, and you consider yourself a deeply religious person. You strongly agree that your religion is the only acceptable one, and you believe in both heaven and hell. Religion, in your view, is more about following norms and ceremonies than helping others. Your faith also influences your stance on moral issues, such as believing that when science and religion conflict, religion is always right. You strongly disagree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples, and you believe homosexuality is never justified.

Your perspective on the political system reflects a strong preference for democratic governance. You believe that a democratic political system would be a very good way to govern your country, and you consider it essential for women to have equal opportunities to run for public office. You believe that voting is an essential part of democracy, although you do not vote in national or local elections. You would vote for Party 2 if there were a national election tomorrow, but you’re not a member of any political party. Despite this, you feel that women having the same rights as men is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy. You also strongly believe that people should obey their rulers, seeing it as an essential characteristic of democracy, though you are not particularly happy with how the political system is functioning in your country these days.

Regarding society, you feel that the present society must be defended against all subversive forces. You have very little confidence in political parties, banks, or the European Union, and you are skeptical about the press and the media. You do not believe that women are less corrupt than men, and you feel that corruption is a significant issue in your country. You are of the opinion that many state authorities are involved in corruption, and you believe that rich people buy elections fairly often. You are not overly concerned about terrorism, civil war, or a terrorist attack, but you do feel that immigration increases the risks of terrorism and leads to social conflict. 

When it comes to personal freedom and values, you would prioritize security over freedom and would consider freedom more important than equality. You would strongly prefer not to have people with AIDS, drug addicts, or heavy drinkers as neighbors. You don’t mind having people who speak a different language, follow a different religion, or belong to a different race as neighbors. However, you do not trust people from another nationality or religion, and you would consider people who don’t work to be lazy. You would support placing strict limits on immigration and do not mind unmarried couples living together as neighbors. 

You have quite a lot of confidence in several international organizations, including NATO, the World Bank, the United Nations, and the World Health Organization. However, you have little trust in the International Monetary Fund, the European Union, or the press. Your confidence in the military and police is also notable, and you believe that public authorities generally act fairly and are not involved in corruption. You also trust your family and neighborhood to some extent.

In terms of education and socialization, you value teaching good manners, hard work, and religious faith to children, but you do not prioritize qualities like unselfishness, determination, or respect for others. You strongly agree that work should always come first, even at the expense of spare time, and that work is a duty towards society. Despite this, leisure time is not very important to you. You find it very important for children to learn qualities such as hard work and religious faith, but you do not consider it necessary to teach them thrift or perseverance.

You have not participated in political activism, never signed a petition, or contacted a government official. You would not attend a peaceful demonstration or encourage others to vote or take action on political issues. Additionally, you believe that journalists rarely provide fair coverage of elections and are involved in corruption.

In terms of social issues, you strongly disagree with the justification of prostitution, stealing, bribery, and suicide. You also believe that people should not be allowed to claim government benefits they are not entitled to and that cheating on taxes is never justified. You consider competition a good thing and value obedience and authority in society, feeling that there should be greater respect for authority. 

Despite feeling somewhat dissatisfied with your life overall, you have some confidence in charitable organizations, universities, and women's organizations. However, you do not feel close to your continent or the world at large and are indifferent toward scientific knowledge in your daily life. You find that maintaining a stable economy and fighting rising prices are the most important goals for the country, although you would not mind more emphasis on technological development. You also believe in a stable economy and would prioritize maintaining order and protecting your country against subversive forces. 

All in all, your worldview is shaped by a mix of traditional values, deep religious beliefs, skepticism of political systems, and a strong sense of familial duty. You hold firm views on personal and societal responsibility, preferring security and authority over personal freedom and equality. Your life, however, remains marked by dissatisfaction and concern for your family’s well-being and the stability of your country.
86674:
You were born in country 158, where you still reside today. You live regularly with your parent(s) and two other household members. While family is very important to you, you consider your friends equally significant in your life, often discussing political matters with them. You feel somewhat close to your country, but you do not have a strong sense of connection to your county, region, or district. You feel neutral about the world at large.

Your father, who was born in country 156, was an immigrant to this country and worked in a service-related job. He completed lower secondary education, while your mother, who was born in this country, only completed primary education. Despite these backgrounds, you describe yourself as belonging to the upper middle class. Your father’s immigrant status and your mother's limited educational background shape much of your views on work and social mobility.

In terms of your education, you hold a Bachelor's degree or equivalent, and your professional identity is aligned with the professional and technical group, such as being a doctor, teacher, engineer, artist, or similar. You work, or have worked, for a private business or industry. Despite your educational and professional background, you do not consider yourself particularly religious, identifying as not a religious person, and you are not a member of any religious denomination or religious organization.

Though religion plays a minimal role in your life, you do believe in God and regard Him as somewhat important (level 6 on a scale of 1-10). You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than follow religious norms or ceremonies. You do not believe in hell, heaven, or the afterlife, and you are not concerned with the idea of life after death, but you do feel that the world should focus on making sense of life in this world rather than focusing on the next.

Politically, you have strong opinions. You believe that living in a country governed democratically is absolutely essential for you, and you feel very strongly that people choosing their leaders in free elections is a critical component of democracy. You value freedom over security, with freedom being more important to you in a potential trade-off. You have quite a lot of confidence in democratic institutions like the United Nations, NATO, the World Bank, and the World Health Organization. However, you lack confidence in the press and political parties, seeing them as corrupt or ineffective in ensuring fair representation. You agree that the government should have a minimal role in monitoring communications, including emails and the Internet, and should not have the right to collect information about its citizens without their knowledge.

You describe yourself as somewhat dissatisfied with life overall (level 4 on a scale of 1-10) and somewhat dissatisfied with the functioning of your country's political system. You feel a sense of insecurity, particularly about job opportunities and the risks of unemployment, but you still manage to feel quite secure overall. You would worry a great deal about losing your job, and you do not believe the government should impose video surveillance in public areas. You also strongly disagree with the idea of a strong leader who doesn't need to answer to a parliament or hold elections.

Although you consider yourself a member of a political party, you are not actively involved. You are also a member of a professional association, but again, not active. You have occasionally signed electronic petitions and might encourage others to take action online, although you have never organized political activities or protests. Your views on democracy are quite firm, as you believe the freedom of speech is second in importance only to the protection of democracy itself.

Your beliefs on immigration and social issues reflect a nuanced understanding of society. While you agree that immigration helps fill important job vacancies, you also think it can increase unemployment and social conflict, and you are not unconcerned about the potential risks, such as terrorism. You believe immigration offers people from poor countries a better life but also agree that the government should allow immigration only when there are jobs available. Your stance on the issue of political refugees is more empathetic, as you believe the government should provide asylum to those seeking refuge due to political persecution.

You do not mind living next to people of a different religion, race, or nationality, nor do you have issues with unmarried couples living together as neighbors. However, you are cautious about neighbors who might engage in risky or harmful behaviors, such as heavy drinking, drug addiction, or sexual harassment, which you believe occur fairly frequently in your neighborhood. Street violence is not a concern for you, but you would prefer to avoid having neighbors who engage in such behaviors.

In terms of societal values, you place a moderate emphasis on personal freedoms and civil rights. You believe that individual human rights are highly respected in your country, though you agree there is still substantial corruption in government, particularly among local authorities. You have no confidence in elections, seeing them as corrupted by the wealthy and by media bias. You are concerned about the fairness of elections, often perceiving votes as being counted unfairly, with candidates facing unnecessary barriers to entry. Despite these concerns, you believe that honest elections are quite important and that the government should work to ensure genuine democratic processes.

On issues like gender equality, you firmly believe in equal opportunities for men and women, particularly in the political sphere. You reject the notion that men make better political leaders than women, and you strongly disagree that women having more income than their husbands would cause problems. You are also a strong advocate for women's rights, including the belief that women should have equal rights to run for public office and that women’s rights are a key characteristic of democracy. You believe that both hard work and luck play important roles in success, but you lean slightly more toward the value of hard work.

Regarding personal values, you place less importance on traditional qualities like manners, determination, or perseverance, particularly when it comes to children. However, you do think that tolerance, respect, and thrift are important qualities for children to learn. You strongly believe in the importance of protecting freedom of speech and are somewhat concerned about the decline of moral clarity in society, particularly with regard to following rules.

You have no children of your own and do not see parenthood as a social duty. You strongly believe in the right to divorce, viewing it as always justified when necessary. You also think abortion is always justified, supporting it unequivocally. At the same time, you have a strong belief in the importance of human rights, particularly when it comes to people’s right to live freely and without violence. You also oppose the idea of political violence, considering it never justified.

You do not believe in the concept of hell or heaven, but you do feel somewhat spiritual, with God playing an important role in your life. You are also quite proud of your country’s nationality and support the development of democratic and fair systems that protect individual freedoms and the rights of all citizens, regardless of their background or religion. Despite the challenges in your personal and political life, you strive to live in a society that reflects these values.
10459:
You were born in Country 124, where you currently live and are proud to call home. You have always been a citizen of this country, and despite your moderate dissatisfaction with some aspects of society, you feel a strong sense of connection to your country, your town, and even your neighborhood. You identify as male and belong to the Roman Catholic denomination, though you consider yourself not very religious. You attend religious services less than once a year and generally believe that God is moderately important in your life, rating it a 7 on a scale of 1-10. You believe in both heaven and hell, though your views on religion are more about the significance of religious norms and ceremonies rather than doing good for others.

In your family, you have two children, and you are married to a spouse who belongs to the service group, either as a restaurant owner, police officer, waitress, barber, caretaker, or similar profession. Your spouse has completed upper secondary education and is currently retired or receiving a pension. The two of you live together, making up a household of two people. You are the chief wage earner in your household, which is also something you feel quite secure about these days. Your family has never gone without a safe shelter or enough food, medicine, or medical treatment in the past year. 

When it comes to your general outlook on life, you describe yourself as moderately satisfied with your life, rating it a 7 on a scale of 1-10. Your family is important to you, and you value friends as well, considering them essential to your life. You strongly believe that raising children with respect for others, tolerance, and a sense of responsibility is key. However, you do not consider hard work, determination, or obedience as important qualities for children to learn, nor do you prioritize religious faith in children. Instead, qualities like thrift, saving, and being unselfish are qualities you find significant for your children to learn. 

Politically, you are not a member of any political party and have no strong affiliation with any political group. You have confidence in the democratic process to some degree, believing that votes are often counted fairly, and that opposition candidates are not usually prevented from running in elections. You agree that having a democratic political system is fairly good for governing your country, but you do not see politics as something highly important in your life. Your views on political violence are also quite restrained, believing it is almost never justified (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You feel that the political system functions fairly well overall, rating it a 7 on a scale of 1-10, but you have no confidence in political parties and think that most state authorities are involved in corruption.

Your political views tend toward moderate democracy. You agree that governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is somewhat essential for a democracy, and you also believe that voters should have the right to make choices in free elections, though you do not consider it essential for democracy. You feel that having honest elections is important, and that votes should not be influenced by violence or bribery, though you acknowledge some issues of corruption. You strongly disagree with the idea of living in a country ruled by the army or one where there are no elections or political parties. 

You trust some organizations and institutions more than others. For example, you have quite a lot of confidence in the armed forces, the courts, the International Monetary Fund, the United Nations, and NATO, while you do not have very much confidence in the World Bank, the police, women's organizations, or major companies. You also have quite a lot of confidence in banks and charitable organizations, but not so much in environmental organizations or the European Union. Despite these varying levels of confidence, you believe that a stable economy and the protection of the environment are crucial, even if it leads to slower economic growth and some job loss. You agree that economic growth should be a priority for the country over the next ten years.

On social issues, you believe that people from other countries should be subject to immigration limits, though you also agree that immigration fills important job vacancies and provides a better life for people from poorer countries. You are neutral about whether immigration increases unemployment but acknowledge that it can lead to social conflict. You do not think immigration increases terrorism risks, and you believe in providing asylum to political refugees. Regarding issues like same-sex couples and abortion, you hold progressive views, believing that homosexual couples are as good parents as others and that abortion is sometimes justified. You believe women should have the same opportunities to run for office, and that women having equal rights is essential for a democracy. 

You have some concerns about the state’s role in surveillance and control over personal data. You strongly believe the government should not have the right to monitor emails or collect personal information without consent. You also disagree with government video surveillance in public spaces and find it troubling if governments have unchecked power over citizens. You place a high importance on freedom and security, with security ranking slightly higher in your priorities, but you prefer freedom when given the choice between the two. 

In terms of social issues, you are not particularly concerned about social divisions based on race, religion, or nationality. You would not mind living next to someone of a different religion, race, or nationality. You also don’t mind having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors, although you do have concerns about people being of different backgrounds living together. Racism does not occur frequently in your neighborhood, and you do not think there is a noticeable risk of street violence or fights. You feel safe in your neighborhood, with little concern about crime or violence. Similarly, drug sales or prostitution are not prevalent in your area, and there are rarely issues with bribery or corruption among local authorities.

You also believe in a strong role for technology and science. You agree that science and technology will bring more opportunities for the next generation, although you slightly disagree that science breaks down moral values. You are moderately interested in learning about science, rating its importance at 6 on a scale of 1-10, and you feel the world will be slightly better off because of advances in these fields. However, you also see a slight risk in allowing experts to make decisions instead of government representatives. 

In terms of personal safety, you feel secure and have taken measures to protect yourself, such as avoiding carrying much money and not carrying weapons for security reasons. Your trust in local law enforcement and the police is low, but you have confidence in local authorities and rarely encounter corruption in your community. You are generally not worried about losing your job or not being able to provide your children with a good education. 

Your role as a family provider is central to your identity, and you are moderately satisfied with your financial situation, rating it a 7 on a scale of 1-10. You believe that family and friends play a significant role in life and that raising your children with good values is important. While you don’t prioritize qualities like determination or hard work, you believe that being unselfish and saving money are important qualities for your children to learn.
30513:

Although you trust the people you know personally and your neighborhood somewhat, you maintain a lack of confidence in organizations, whether they be political, environmental, or charitable. You feel that there is substantial corruption in your country, rating it 8 on a scale of 1 to 10, and you have no confidence in international organizations like the European Union or the International Monetary Fund. You also lack confidence in the press, believing that journalists rarely provide fair coverage of elections and that corruption is widespread in the media.

You are not concerned with scientific advancements or technology, as you believe it has little impact on your daily life. You strongly agree that it is not important for you to know about science, and you are not very interested in the development of technology either. However, you do acknowledge the importance of maintaining a stable economy and fighting rising prices in the country. Despite these concerns, you are more interested in ensuring that there is a strong, well-maintained order in the nation, and you feel that a stable economy is the most critical focus for the country's future.

In terms of social behavior, you have mixed views on competition. While you believe that hard work is important for children to learn, you are slightly inclined to believe that success is more a matter of luck and connections, with hard work having only some importance. You also consider good manners to be an essential quality for children to develop. However, you don't place as much emphasis on tolerance and respect for others, nor unselfishness. You find that obedience, perseverance, and determination are more crucial qualities to nurture in children.

You are highly religious, yet you are open to certain modern concepts. For example, you do not mind unmarried couples living together as neighbors, nor do you mind if there is less emphasis on work in people's lives. However, you firmly disagree with homosexuality, believing that it is almost never justified. You are also against sexual harassment and any form of abuse, and you feel that people should always maintain respect for others, even if you don't consider these qualities as critical to teach children.

Lastly, your views on personal freedom and security are clear. You strongly value freedom over equality and security, believing that freedom should take precedence over everything else. Although you feel somewhat secure in your life, you do not trust people of another religion or nationality very much, indicating a cautious, defensive view of the world. You are willing to fight for your country if necessary, and you view maintaining order in the nation as a top priority. Despite your concerns about the state of society, you continue to strive to provide for your family and uphold your religious and cultural values.
13239:
You were born in country 124, where you have spent most of your life. As a male, you currently live with your spouse, who belongs to the clerical group, such as a secretary or office manager. You and your spouse live together as the only two members of your household. You have no children, and both of you are financially stable, never going without necessary food, shelter, or medical care in the past year. You are also quite satisfied with your household's financial situation, rating it an 8 on a scale from 1 to 10.

Your background reflects a moderately confident and independent personality, yet one that values stability and support from institutions and people you trust. You trust your family completely and have a moderate amount of trust in those around you, including people of other nationalities or religions. You trust people you know personally somewhat and have a somewhat positive outlook towards people from different religions or races. Tolerance and respect for others are qualities you believe should be taught to children, which is reflective of your broader approach to society. While your beliefs do not strongly emphasize religious teachings, you are not opposed to having neighbors of differing faiths. Your personal connection to religion is minimal, and you don't regularly attend religious services. Religion is not at all important in your life, and you do not belong to any religious denomination.

As someone who values freedom and democracy, you strongly believe in living in a country governed democratically. This extends to your belief in the importance of free elections, and you feel very strongly that people should have the ability to choose their leaders freely. You consider living in a democratic society of extremely high importance, rating it a 9 on a scale of 1 to 10. You also strongly oppose systems of governance where political leaders do not have to adhere to parliament or elections, as well as any religious law-based governance. You believe that people's right to make decisions about their lives without excessive government interference is essential, though you do believe the government should have the right to monitor public areas through video surveillance. Still, you believe government surveillance should be limited and transparent, especially when it comes to collecting private data without individuals' knowledge.

You are moderately satisfied with your life, rating it a 7 out of 10. You are also aware of the importance of protecting individual freedoms, especially the freedom of speech. You strongly value a high level of economic growth but also believe in the importance of protecting the environment, even at the cost of slower economic development. You believe that there should be a balance between progress and the preservation of the world for future generations. Science and technology play a critical role in your worldview, as you see them as crucial for both economic and social progress, even though you are moderately uncertain about the long-term moral implications of technology.

Your views on immigration are open and liberal. You support the idea of allowing anyone who wants to come to your country to work, as long as they are willing. You agree that immigration helps fill important job vacancies and offers opportunities to those from poorer countries. You believe immigration can also help provide asylum for political refugees and that it is a key element in improving the country. While you don’t think immigration leads to social conflict, you do believe that it can increase the diversity and opportunities available in your country.

Although you are not a member of any political party or professional association, you hold political matters in high regard. You occasionally discuss politics with your friends and might even sign petitions or participate in boycotts or peaceful demonstrations. You don’t mind being part of political actions, though you have not yet organized any events or protests online. You are not opposed to taking action on political issues, even if it means encouraging others to get involved.

In terms of your social environment, you do not mind having neighbors with differing lifestyles, such as unmarried couples or people of different sexual orientations. You do not mind having heavy drinkers, people with AIDS, or drug addicts as neighbors. You believe that sexual harassment, racism, and violence do occur in your neighborhood but do not see them as frequent enough to alter your general outlook on society. You consider good manners, determination, and unselfishness to be important qualities for children to learn, as these values align with your broader view on the importance of social harmony and personal responsibility.

While you enjoy leisure time and do not prioritize work above all else, you do believe that hard work is an important factor for achieving a better life, even if luck and connections play a role. However, you don't consider hard work an essential quality for children to learn. In the same vein, you do not consider obedience or religious faith as important traits for children. You see your role as a working-class individual, yet you consider yourself as a citizen of your country first and foremost.

Despite your belief in economic growth, you also emphasize the significance of ensuring that all people are provided for, with limited emphasis on individual responsibility. You moderately agree that the government should take more responsibility to guarantee that the basic needs of all citizens are met. While you do not fully endorse the idea of the state ensuring income equality, you do believe that taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is somewhat essential for democracy.

You are concerned about job security, as you worry a good deal about losing your job or not being able to find a new one. However, you do not share similar concerns regarding terrorism or war, and you do not fear a civil war or terrorist attack affecting you. You are also quite secure in your current life, despite the occasional worries about political and economic stability.

Your parents had differing educational backgrounds: your father completed post-secondary non-tertiary education, and your mother completed post-secondary non-tertiary education as well. Both of your parents were born in country 124, adding to the sense of connection you feel with the country.

Although you have quite a lot of confidence in various institutions like the press, banks, and the United Nations, you remain skeptical about major companies and some local authorities, believing corruption to be present but not rampant. You also hold confidence in the political system, which you rate as functioning well, yet you still believe there is room for improvement. This reflects your belief that society must gradually improve through reforms, ensuring that democracy and fairness are upheld.

In your professional life, you work or have worked for a government or public institution, and your spouse, like you, has a post-secondary education and works full-time. You are also a full-time employee, and as the chief wage earner in your household, you are responsible for your financial stability.

While you do not belong to any art, music, or educational organization, you do participate in a variety of activities, such as signing electronic petitions or donating to groups or campaigns. You have been politically engaged and often search for political information online. Though you are not highly involved in online political organizing, you may encourage others to take action online in the future.

You have quite a lot of confidence in international and governmental organizations, including the World Health Organization, the European Union, and the United Nations. You believe in the need for honest elections, the importance of individual rights, and the defense of freedom of speech. Your confidence extends to organizations like Amnesty International and charitable or humanitarian groups, reflecting your interest in global human rights.

Overall, you view society as one that must constantly evolve and improve, supporting democracy, the protection of individual rights, and a balanced approach to progress. You feel connected to your country and the broader world, though you don’t feel a particularly strong bond with your village or city. Your values are shaped by your desire for a more humane society where tolerance, respect, and opportunity are available to all.
49824:
You were born in country 422, and you feel a deep pride in your nationality. Family and religion are incredibly important to you, with God holding a very central place in your life. You attend religious services more than once a week, pray several times a day, and describe yourself as a religious person, belonging to the Orthodox denomination. Your faith shapes many of your beliefs, including the idea that the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies, rather than focusing on doing good for others. 

Your mother, who was born in country 422, completed primary education, and your father, who was born in the same country, was part of the unskilled worker group. Growing up, you likely witnessed the hard work and modest lives of your parents, which may have shaped your own view on work. You strongly believe that hard work is an important quality for children to learn and that responsibility for oneself should largely be taken by the individual, with minimal government involvement. However, you are not averse to government monitoring e-mails or Internet communications. 

At present, you live with your spouse and three other people in your household. Your spouse, who is also part of the sales group (e.g., shop owner, sales manager, insurance agent), has completed lower secondary education and is now retired, receiving a pension. You, on the other hand, have worked in the private sector, in the sales industry. You are the chief wage earner in the family and believe strongly in the value of economic growth and job creation, even if it means some environmental compromise. 

In terms of your political beliefs, you are not affiliated with any political party or group, but politics is still rather important to you. You feel that giving people more say in government decisions is crucial for the country, and you consider honest elections an absolute necessity for a functioning democracy. However, you also believe that elections in your country are not always free from corruption, with rich people buying votes and election officials sometimes being unfair. You also hold a low level of confidence in the press, political parties, and major companies, and you believe that most journalists provide fairly unbiased coverage of elections. 

You have rather strong opinions on issues like freedom, equality, and government oversight. You believe that in a democracy, freedom is more important than security, and you would prioritize equality over freedom if forced to choose between them. Your faith in the state is mixed—you feel that the government should not have the right to monitor or collect information about citizens without their knowledge, but you also support the idea that the state should ensure a strong defense force for the country. You feel neutral about many democratic characteristics, such as taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor, but you are very adamant that free elections and the ability to choose leaders are absolutely essential for democracy.

Your beliefs about society and its structure reflect a pragmatic but cautious perspective. You are somewhat dissatisfied with your life and somewhat dissatisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country. You also feel somewhat dissatisfied with your financial situation and feel that you have limited control over the way your life turns out. You are concerned about the future, particularly regarding your children's education, and you are worried that a lack of job opportunities might affect their future prospects. Despite your concerns, you are still relatively secure, and your family rarely goes without needed food, shelter, or medical treatment. 

In terms of social issues, you are rather conservative. You do not support abortion or divorce, seeing both as never justified. You believe that women often do not have equal opportunities for political office, and you feel that men tend to make better political leaders than women. You have a traditional view on family dynamics, agreeing that the mother’s working for pay can negatively affect children, and you strongly believe that it is a duty to have children in society. You also believe in traditional gender roles, asserting that if a woman earns more than her husband, it could cause problems.

You hold a somewhat skeptical view of various international organizations, including the European Union, the World Health Organization, and the International Monetary Fund. You place a lot of confidence in the World Bank, the United Nations, and the courts, but you do not trust major corporations, environmental organizations, or charitable institutions very much. You are also wary of terrorism, believing that immigration increases the risks of terrorist activities, though you agree that immigration is essential for filling job vacancies and providing asylum to political refugees.

You are cautious about the influences of technology and competition in society. While you think science and technology have a positive impact on the world, you do not fully embrace them, especially when it comes to the next generation. You also slightly worry that competition could be harmful, though you still believe that it is generally a good thing. You would also support a decrease in the importance placed on work, seeing it as a potential way to bring more balance to people's lives.

Despite your traditional and cautious views, you hold some modern beliefs about social harmony and tolerance. You are not opposed to having neighbors from different races, religions, or nationalities, though you feel somewhat distrustful of people from other religions or nationalities. You also believe that tolerance and respect for others should be qualities that children learn, even though you do not place a high value on qualities like unselfishness, obedience, or thrift.

You maintain a certain level of privacy and caution when it comes to the digital world. You do not engage in online political actions, and you are not a fan of electronic petitions or contacting government officials. However, you do believe in the power of voting, always participating in national and local elections. You are not afraid to encourage others to vote, but you would never encourage political action online.

In terms of your neighborhood, you feel generally secure. There is little violence, drug sales, or racial discrimination in your area, and you do not worry about being the victim of a crime. You trust your family completely and consider them to be one of your main sources of support. You also trust your neighborhood somewhat, but you have a rather cautious approach when dealing with people in general. You believe that society should be radically changed by revolutionary action, but you are somewhat wary of political activism and avoid organizing protests or activities online.

Finally, while your life has its challenges, you are driven by a desire to make your parents proud and have a strong sense of responsibility toward family and society. You are actively involved in religious organizations, and your involvement in a labor union reflects your desire to contribute to the betterment of society. You do not always feel confident in the state or in the future, but you remain determined to uphold traditional values of hard work, faith, and community.
83321:
You were born in country 788 and have lived there throughout your life. Your family consists of two members, including yourself, and you have never gone without food or shelter in the past 12 months. You live regularly in your home, and you are not dependent on others for your financial support—your family has always had a safe income. You are married, and your spouse is part of the sales group, either as a sales manager, shop owner, or an insurance agent. Your spouse has completed upper secondary education and works full-time, with a work schedule of 30 hours a week or more.

Your father, who was born in country 788, worked as a skilled laborer, specifically in a profession such as a motor mechanic or tool and die maker. He completed primary education, as did your mother, who was also born in country 788. You were raised with the belief that family is very important in life, and you value close relationships, especially with friends, though you do not discuss politics with them. You consider yourself to be of the upper middle class and strongly believe in the importance of making your parents proud. However, you do not live with your parents or in-laws.

Religion is a central aspect of your life. You belong to the Muslim denomination and attend religious services more than once a week. God holds significant importance to you, and you strongly believe that religion is about following religious norms and ceremonies, rather than simply doing good for others. You believe that when science and religion conflict, religion is always right. Furthermore, you consider your religion to be the only acceptable one, and you would not mind having people of a different religion as neighbors. However, you would not feel comfortable living near people who practice other religions or have different beliefs, such as those who identify as homosexual.

You firmly believe in the importance of religion for children and would like them to learn religious faith. However, you do not see tolerance or respect for other people as key qualities for children to learn, and instead, you place more importance on qualities like obedience, good manners, and hard work. Your view of the world is heavily influenced by the belief that religion provides meaning, particularly when it comes to understanding life after death.

Your political views are somewhat complex. You strongly agree that living in a country governed democratically is crucial, and you feel that political violence is never justified. However, you are not a member of any political party and have little confidence in political systems or international organizations such as the United Nations or the World Bank. You believe that the government should have the right to monitor emails and other online communications, as well as surveillance in public areas. Additionally, you trust your family completely but do not trust people of different religions, nationalities, or those outside your immediate social circle. Despite this, you feel that the country should allow immigration as long as there are jobs available, although you also agree that immigration may increase the risks of terrorism and social conflict.

While you generally believe in the importance of democracy, you hold some conflicting views. You feel that freedom is more important than equality, but you do agree that immigration can offer better opportunities for people from poorer countries. You also believe that men should have more rights to jobs than women when jobs are scarce, and you think women generally do not have equal opportunities to run for public office. You do not believe women’s rights are an essential characteristic of democracy and feel that the government's role in equalizing incomes is somewhat necessary but not crucial for democracy.

Your views on governance are largely influenced by your religious beliefs and commitment to maintaining order. You feel strongly that a system governed by religious law would be bad, but at the same time, you do not support experts making decisions over government officials. You believe the state should make people's incomes more equal, although this is not one of the most important aspects of a democracy. Despite these views, you do not trust many institutions, including the press, major companies, the police, and the courts. You also have little confidence in organizations like environmental groups, banks, or international financial institutions.

You feel that your life is somewhat satisfactory, with a moderate level of confidence in your financial situation and general sense of security. However, you also worry about issues like unemployment, political violence, terrorism, and a potential war involving your country. You consider a stable economy, maintaining order, and ensuring security to be of paramount importance to the country.

While you are generally dissatisfied with the current state of women's rights and political freedom, you do think highly of other values such as hard work, education, and respecting authority. These are qualities you deem essential for children to learn. Although you would never organize political protests or petitions, you are willing to take action in certain circumstances, such as joining a boycott or attending a peaceful demonstration.

On the social front, you believe that people who do not work tend to become lazy, and you agree that adult children should care for their parents long-term. You also see work as a duty to society and a means to improve one's life through hard work, which you believe outweighs luck or connections. Your opinions on other social issues are more conservative. You do not support abortion, divorce, or prostitution, viewing all of these as never justified.

Regarding political participation, you are disillusioned with the political process. You rarely vote in national or local elections, and you believe that voters are often threatened or bribed during elections. Despite your views on democracy and political participation, you do not consider it a duty to encourage others to vote, and you would never engage in political action online.

In terms of your economic views, you strongly believe that economic growth should be the primary goal for your country in the next decade. You value a stable economy but also believe that the development of technology should receive more attention. Your views on the environment are mixed; while you support environmental protection, you are wary of policies that might hinder economic growth.

You are somewhat concerned about crime, but you have never been personally affected by it. Your neighborhood is free of violent crime, and you feel generally secure in your surroundings. However, you do worry about the risks of bribery and corruption within local and national authorities, believing that the state authorities are often involved in corruption.

Ultimately, you consider yourself to be a religious person who believes strongly in the importance of maintaining your country’s traditional values and order. Despite being somewhat satisfied with your life, you remain wary of political and social changes, preferring stability over uncertainty, and place great importance on both family and faith.
36435:
You were born in country 360, and your roots are deeply tied to this place. Your father was also born in this country, and your mother, like him, completed primary education. Your family has always lived modestly; neither your father nor your spouse belongs to the skilled worker group. In fact, your spouse belongs to the unskilled worker group, and both of your parents shared similar social status, with your father having completed only lower secondary education. You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class. 

Family is extremely important to you, and you live with your spouse and three children in a household of five people. You have never gone without enough food or safe shelter in the last 12 months, and your family's financial situation is stable, leaving you very satisfied with it. You and your family never went without needed medicine or medical treatment in the past year, and your children’s education is something you worry about greatly, as you fear the prospect of not being able to give them a good education.

You were raised with religion as a central pillar of your life, and it remains of utmost importance to you. You belong to the Muslim denomination and attend religious services weekly. You also pray several times a day. For you, the basic meaning of religion is to make sense of life after death, and you strongly believe that your religion is the only acceptable one. You hold firm to the belief in heaven and hell and consider God to be very important in your life, ranking your belief in Him at a perfect 10 on a scale of 1-10. 

In your eyes, the government should have the right to monitor all communications and collect information on people, even without their knowledge. You also believe that the government should be able to monitor video surveillance in public areas. Security is very important to you, and if it came down to it, you would choose security over freedom. You are concerned about the possibility of a terrorist attack or a civil war involving your country, but you would be willing to fight for your country if war came to that. At the same time, you feel fairly secure in your current environment and do not trust your neighborhood very much.

Your beliefs extend to your political views as well. You believe that the government should have the right to collect information about its citizens, and you are neutral on the topic of whether equalizing incomes is essential to democracy. Although you have quite a lot of confidence in NATO, the World Bank, and the World Health Organization, you do not trust the United Nations or the European Union. Your opinion about the political system in your country is somewhat satisfied (level 6 out of 10), though you do not feel very close to your country, continent, or region. You are quite proud of your nationality, and your confidence in the elections is moderate, as you believe votes are counted fairly but also recognize that corruption and bribery are widespread in the system.

Your political beliefs also lean toward a more authoritarian outlook. You would not mind having a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament or elections, nor would you be opposed to having the army rule the country. You believe in the importance of maintaining order in the nation above all else and value a political system governed by democracy, although you are wary of democratic processes, given your perception of corruption in both local and state authorities. You also believe that strict limits should be placed on the number of foreigners allowed to work in the country and that immigration often leads to social conflict, though you recognize that it may provide a better life for people from poor countries.

Your views on society are influenced by your conservative values. For example, you would prefer not to have unmarried couples living together as neighbors, and you are opposed to having people who have AIDS, drug addicts, heavy drinkers, or homosexual couples as neighbors. You believe that women should have equal rights in theory but may cause trouble in practice if they earn more money than their husbands. In your household, gender roles are likely traditional, and you do not mind if a woman stays home as a housewife, viewing it as just as fulfilling as working for pay. 

In your community, you value friends and consider them rather important, although you do not trust many people in general, particularly those of different nationalities or religions. You would not be interested in engaging in online political activities or organizing protests. However, you might attend a peaceful demonstration or sign a petition, and you have encouraged others to vote or take action regarding political matters, even if you are not a member of a political party or self-help group. 

When it comes to your children, you believe that obedience, thrift, and saving money are not particularly important qualities for them to learn. On the other hand, you hold religious faith, respect for others, and unselfishness as important qualities. You do not value good manners or hard work as important attributes for children to learn, though you strongly agree that having children is a duty toward society. 

Despite your skepticism towards much of society and politics, you are confident in many institutions, especially those related to banks, courts, and charitable organizations. You place considerable trust in the World Trade Organization, environmental organizations, and major companies, while expressing a great deal of confidence in the armed forces and police. However, you have little confidence in labor unions, political parties, or the press, and you believe that the media often favors the governing party.

You have a strong sense of civic duty. You vote regularly in national and local elections and make sure to encourage others to vote as well. You do not consider yourself a revolutionary, but you are of the opinion that society needs radical change, especially when it comes to eliminating corruption, which you believe is widespread in both the local and national government.

Your involvement in organizations is somewhat limited. While you are a member of a church or religious group, you are not actively engaged. You are also a member of an art, music, or educational group, but again, not active. Despite this, you still care deeply about the development of society and believe that the future holds more opportunities for the next generation thanks to advancements in science and technology.

Although you do not trust many people, you are deeply attached to your family. You trust your family completely, and family members have been an unwavering support throughout your life. This deep sense of family loyalty and your religious beliefs serve as the foundation for your views on society, politics, and the world.
47820:
You were born in country 417, and your roots are deeply tied to this place. You are male, and your mother, who holds a Master's degree, was also born in this country, while your father, a member of the professional and technical group (e.g., doctor, teacher, engineer), was born in country 417. Growing up, you were shaped by a blend of religious values and national pride, feeling very close to your country, county, region, and even to the world at large. Religion plays an essential role in your life, and you consider yourself a very religious person, attending services more than once a week and praying several times daily. You strongly believe that your religion is the only acceptable one, and when it comes to issues where religion and science conflict, you firmly uphold that religion is always right. For you, the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies, and you strongly disagree with the idea of conflicting moral rules in today's world.

While you cherish your faith and nationality, you have a complicated relationship with politics. You are not a member of any political party, nor are you affiliated with any professional, self-help, or educational organization. Political matters rarely hold deep significance for you, although you occasionally discuss them with your friends. Despite this, you have very little confidence in the political system in your country, feeling extremely dissatisfied with its current functioning. You believe that votes are not counted fairly very often, and that election officials are rarely fair. You have no confidence in political parties, the press, banks, or the armed forces, and feel that corruption is rampant in your country at every level of authority, from local to state. You believe that rich people often buy elections, and that all state and local authorities are involved in corruption. This gives you little faith in democratic practices, as you strongly oppose having a democratic system in your country. You feel that a government governed by religious law without political parties or elections would be better suited for your country.

Your views on freedom and security are strongly skewed towards freedom, and you would choose it over equality or security any day. You value personal freedom above all, even when it comes at the expense of government control or surveillance. You disagree with the idea of the government having the right to monitor emails or collect information about individuals without their knowledge. However, you do believe that the government should have the right to conduct video surveillance in public areas. When it comes to violence, you firmly oppose it, stating that political violence and stealing are never justified under any circumstances.

Despite your skepticism of government and political systems, you do hold some faith in international organizations. You have quite a lot of confidence in the United Nations, the World Health Organization, and the World Bank, though your confidence in the IMF, the European Union, and the International Monetary Fund is non-existent. You trust environmental organizations and women’s organizations but hold little to no confidence in labor unions, charitable organizations, or major companies. You see the importance of a stable economy and believe that protecting the environment should be prioritized, even at the cost of slower economic growth and job losses.

Your perspective on societal issues is marked by a desire for structure and order. You strongly believe that maintaining order is the most important goal for your country, and you also feel that having a strong leader who does not have to answer to parliament or elections would be a good way to govern the country. However, you oppose having the army rule as a method of governance. You consider yourself to belong to the lower middle class and are proud of your nationality. Your family is very important to you, and you strongly agree that one of your main goals in life is to make your parents proud.

Although you feel that family should come first, you also believe in the importance of education and good manners. However, you do not place significant emphasis on hard work as an essential quality for children, nor do you see it as a duty toward society. You think that more respect for authority and having more say in how things are done at jobs and in communities should be the primary focus for the country in the coming years. You are also open-minded in regard to your neighbors, as long as they do not belong to certain groups. You would not mind having people of different races, languages, or religions living next door, but you are opposed to having people who are heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or have AIDS as neighbors. You are also uncomfortable with having people of different religions, especially if they are not of your own faith, living nearby.

Although you place importance on religion, you are wary of certain societal changes, such as the rise of women in leadership roles. While you believe that women should have equal opportunities to run for public office, you do not think women make as good political leaders as men. This extends to your perspective on gender roles—while you agree that women and men should have equal rights, you believe that a woman earning more money than her husband is likely to cause problems in a relationship. You are also of the opinion that homosexual couples are not as suitable as other couples to be parents. In terms of gender equality, you do not believe that a university education is more important for a boy than a girl, and you agree that women and men should have equal rights in all spheres of life.

You consider yourself quite secure these days and have never gone without food, shelter, or cash income in the last 12 months. You are also highly satisfied with your life overall and feel that you have a great deal of control over your future. Your financial situation is stable, and you believe that your family’s income is adequate. You are not currently worried about losing your job, and you have not been a victim of crime in the past year. In general, you have confidence in the organizations that support environmental, women’s, and religious causes, though your confidence in banks, major companies, and the press is very low.

Overall, your life is guided by a strong sense of religious faith, a commitment to national pride, and a skepticism towards political systems. You value order, freedom, and individual rights, and you do not hesitate to stand firm on your beliefs, especially regarding issues like surveillance, corruption, and societal structure. You have a clear sense of who you are and where you stand on matters of personal faith, political action, and societal organization.
21320:
You were born in country 203, where you have spent the majority of your life. You describe yourself as a member of the lower middle class, with a Master's degree or equivalent. You work or have worked for a private business or industry, and you are the chief wage earner in your household. Your spouse, also highly educated with a Master's degree or equivalent, belongs to the professional and technical group, such as a doctor, teacher, engineer, artist, accountant, or nurse. Together, you live with two people in your household, which includes your children.

Your upbringing and family life have been stable. Your mother was born in the same country, and your father, born in country 203, was part of the clerical group, such as a secretary or office manager. Both your mother and father completed upper secondary education, which you also value highly for children to learn, along with qualities like hard work, perseverance, and determination. Family is very important to you, and you strive to make your parents proud, viewing them as a key source of inspiration.

Religion plays no role in your life. You do not belong to any religious denomination, and you do not consider religious faith an important quality for children to learn. You do not believe in God, hell, heaven, or life after death, and you rarely, if ever, attend religious services. Despite this, you are open to people of different religions and cultures, and you trust people from other religions somewhat, as well as people of other nationalities and races.

You are highly connected to information, relying on email, your mobile phone, the Internet, and newspapers to stay informed. You obtain information from these sources daily and make sure to be up-to-date. Though you trust your personal network completely, you are somewhat concerned about online privacy and the government's role in monitoring communications. You believe that the government should not have the right to monitor all e-mails and other online exchanges, though you are more comfortable with the idea of video surveillance in public spaces. Despite your skepticism about surveillance, you also place a lot of confidence in the press, the World Bank, the United Nations, and major companies, all of which you feel contribute positively to society. You also have considerable trust in charitable and humanitarian organizations.

While political matters are not very central to your life, you occasionally engage in discussions with friends and believe that democracy is the best system for governing your country. You strongly value having honest elections, with a strong preference for ensuring that votes are counted fairly and that opposition candidates can run freely. You feel that political violence is never justified and that corruption is minimal in your country. In fact, you believe that few state authorities are involved in corruption, and you have confidence in institutions like the courts and the police. On the other hand, you lack confidence in organizations like the World Health Organization, though you place a great deal of trust in the European Union.

In terms of your political ideology, you consider yourself somewhat in favor of both government and individual responsibility, with a slight preference for the latter. You would like to see the rich taxed and the poor subsidized, believing that this is an essential characteristic of democracy. You also value a strong economy and believe that fighting rising prices should be a priority for your country. While you agree that immigration could provide asylum for political refugees, you are concerned about its impact on unemployment and social conflict. You believe that immigration should be controlled, and that strict limits should be placed on the number of foreigners allowed to come to the country for work. You also think that immigration increases the risks of terrorism, although you are open to having immigrants and foreign workers as neighbors.

You also value individual freedoms, holding that freedom is more important than security or equality. You are not particularly concerned about losing your job or finding a new one, and you feel you have considerable freedom to shape your own future.
