You also place value on the concept of freedom and the ability to make choices in life, feeling moderately in control of your own destiny.

You are currently divorced, yet you remain deeply committed to your faith, family, and the principles that guide your life.
70011:
You were born in country 604, and despite your life here, you don't feel particularly close to your country or your region, village, or city. While you take pride in your nationality, you have little confidence in the local or national authorities, believing that most of them, including local authorities, are involved in corruption. You often feel insecure and worry a great deal about the possibility of a civil war or a war involving your country, and you are especially concerned about the threat of terrorism. This sense of worry extends to your worries about losing your job or not finding a job, and the ability to give your children a good education. Despite these concerns, you believe you have substantial freedom of choice over your life, ranking it an 8 on a scale of 1-10. 

You live with your spouse and children, along with your parent(s), in a household of four people. Your spouse has never had a job, and you are the chief wage earner for your family. Your spouse is or was a housewife and has completed lower secondary education. While you consider family very important in your life, you are not a religious person, despite the fact that religion plays a significant role for you in other ways. You believe that God is very important in your life and that the basic meaning of religion is to make sense of life after death, though you are not a member of any religious denomination or organization. You attend religious services once a month and pray daily, yet you also identify as not very religious overall. 

Your father, born in country 604, was part of the semi-skilled worker group (such as a bus driver or carpenter), and he completed upper secondary education. Your mother, who was born in this country, completed lower secondary education. You describe yourself as belonging to the service group, working for a private business or industry. Although you do not consider yourself particularly politically active, you occasionally discuss political matters with friends and have attended peaceful demonstrations before. You are not a member of any political party, and you do not trust political parties or their elections, believing that voters are not offered a genuine choice in this country. You do not believe the elections in this country are fair or free, with frequent allegations of bribery, voter intimidation, and the prevention of opposition candidates from running. Furthermore, you think that the government is involved in corruption and that the press is biased, often favoring the governing party. 

You have a moderate level of confidence in major companies and the press, as well as in banks, but little confidence in political parties, the courts, and the police. You also do not trust your neighborhood very much, though you do have some trust in your family. In terms of political beliefs, you believe that protecting freedom of speech is the most important priority for your country and that democracy, though flawed, is the best system for governing. However, you still think that some level of government surveillance is acceptable and support the idea that the government should take more responsibility to ensure everyone is provided for.

Although you feel it is important to have equality and freedom, you prioritize security over freedom, considering it more important. You believe that when jobs are scarce, men should have more rights to employment than women and strongly agree that work should always come first. This belief in the duty to work extends to your view that work is a duty towards society and that people who do not work are not lazy. You strongly believe in the importance of hard work and believe that in the long run, hard work brings a better life. You also have a strong belief in competition and in the idea that people choosing their leaders in free elections is an essential characteristic of democracy. 

Although you do not value leisure time very much, you believe that religious faith, tolerance, and respect for others are important qualities for children to learn. You also consider good manners an essential quality for children, and you feel that parents should take care of their children long-term, which aligns with your strong belief that one of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud. 

While you do not mind having neighbors of different religions, races, or nationalities, you are wary of people who practice different religions, not trusting them as much. You are not comfortable with having drug addicts or people with AIDS as neighbors, but you are open-minded about the presence of unmarried couples living together. You disagree with the idea that women are less corrupt than men, and while you agree that women should have equal rights, you also believe that men should sometimes take priority in the workforce when jobs are scarce. 

Your political views include the belief that the government should be involved in providing for everyone, but you do not feel that the government's role should be to equalize incomes or provide tax breaks for the wealthy. You are opposed to the idea of a system governed by religious law and dislike the idea of experts making decisions about the country instead of the government. You believe that government monitoring of internet activity, such as emails, is necessary for security reasons. However, you also think that allowing people more say in how things are done at their jobs and communities should be a top priority for your country. 

You are not satisfied with the current political system and feel that it requires significant reform. At the same time, you have a moderate level of confidence in environmental organizations and believe that the government should prioritize the protection of the environment, even if it means economic slowdown. You are actively involved in a self-help or mutual aid group and have donated to various causes in the past. You have little interest in technology development but do believe that science and technology can offer opportunities for future generations. However, you are not a fan of science undermining traditional moral values.

Overall, you are not highly satisfied with the political and social system in your country but find contentment in other areas of your life. You are concerned about the future and the well-being of your children, and while you hold some traditional beliefs, you also support certain modern values related to democracy, human rights, and hard work.
83228:
You were born in country 788 and have always been a proud citizen, feeling a strong connection to both your country and its local community. Growing up, your father belonged to the farm worker group, working as a farm laborer, while your mother had little formal education, perhaps only early childhood schooling. Your family’s situation wasn’t always luxurious, but you never went without food or shelter, and never faced the fear of not having enough income. In fact, both you and your family managed to avoid these hardships for the past 12 months, which you are grateful for. 

You live with your spouse and two children in a household of four. Your spouse, who also comes from a humble background, belongs to the farm worker group and has completed primary education. However, she is currently a housewife and not otherwise employed. Family is incredibly important to you, and despite your lack of trust in your extended family, you still place significant value on the close-knit bond you share with your immediate family.

You consider yourself to be quite religious, belonging to the Muslim denomination, with your faith playing a crucial role in your daily life. You pray several times a day, attend religious services more than once a week, and deeply believe in the significance of religion in shaping one’s actions and life. For you, the meaning of religion extends beyond rituals—it’s about doing good for others and finding a sense of purpose, particularly in life after death. You strongly agree that your religion is the only acceptable one, and view the concept of hell and heaven as a key part of your belief system. While religion forms a significant part of your worldview, you also believe that obedience and respect for authority are important values to instill in children, alongside hard work, thrift, and unselfishness.

Politically, you are not a member of any political party and hold a rather critical view of the political landscape. You believe the government should have the right to monitor all emails and other internet communications, and that it’s essential for the state to make people’s incomes more equal, especially through taxing the rich to subsidize the poor. However, you do not have much confidence in political parties, nor in major international organizations like the World Bank, NATO, the United Nations, or the European Union. You feel that political violence is rarely justified, but believe that government elections, while occasionally fair, are often swayed by external influences, such as wealthy individuals buying votes or the governing party influencing the media. In fact, you agree that TV news often favors the governing party. You also believe that voters aren’t always offered a genuine choice, and that election officials tend to be unfair. Yet, despite your skepticism about the electoral process, you always vote in national and local elections, and have even encouraged others to do so. 

You believe in the importance of maintaining order in the nation and consider it the second most crucial goal for your country. However, you would feel strongly opposed to governance led by a single, strong leader without elections or a parliament. You see democracy as a system where people should be allowed to choose their leaders, but you believe it’s also necessary for governments to take responsibility for providing long-term care for their citizens and to offer asylum to political refugees. That said, you feel that democracy isn’t perfect in your country, and that the importance of equal opportunities for women in running for public office is somewhat overemphasized. 

Though you believe that people from other countries should be allowed to work here if there are available jobs, you do not trust people of different nationalities or religions much. Additionally, while you feel it would be bad for the country to be governed solely by religious law, you have no problem with having unmarried couples or people of different religions as neighbors. However, you do feel that racial discrimination is frequent in your neighborhood, and that people like you often have to deal with corruption in dealing with local authorities.

You feel a strong sense of pride in your nationality, and even when it comes to global matters, you believe your region and continent are important to you. Despite this, you are not very close to the wider world and feel you must be very cautious in dealing with people, especially those from different backgrounds. Tolerance and respect for others are qualities you think should be cultivated in children. However, you find it hard to say whether immigration fills important job vacancies or leads to social conflict.

In terms of your personal life, you describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class and are somewhat dissatisfied with your life. You don't worry much about losing your job or not finding another, and you are not particularly concerned about your family's financial situation. You place little emphasis on leisure time, and instead, consider hard work a duty to society. While you agree that men should have more rights to jobs than women when employment is scarce, you also believe in equality to some extent, especially when it comes to offering a better life for people from poorer countries through immigration.

Regarding social issues, you are not particularly supportive of political activism and would never attend a peaceful demonstration. You also disagree with boycotts or other forms of political protest. However, you do believe that competition in society is somewhat harmful, although you see its benefits. You hold a rather neutral stance toward society, feeling that it should be gradually improved by reforms, but not drastically altered. You also don’t mind having people of a different race, religion, or language as neighbors, but you have a deep-rooted belief that some moral rules are difficult to follow and that, at times, decisions based on those rules can be confusing.

Finally, your commitment to your family and your religion is a driving force in your life. Despite the challenges, you strongly believe in making your parents proud and upholding traditional values such as respect, obedience, and hard work. While you are not overly concerned with societal changes or technological advancements, you do see the importance of a well-structured, orderly society that emphasizes responsibility and perseverance.
32088:
You were born in your home country and consider yourself a proud citizen. Your father and mother both hail from country 156, with your father being an immigrant. Religion plays no role in your life; you do not believe in God, hell, or heaven, and you are an atheist. You do not consider religious faith an important quality for children to learn. Politics, though somewhat relevant to your daily life, is not an area of high personal importance. You feel somewhat satisfied with how the political system operates in your country, though you acknowledge there is a noticeable amount of corruption in your country. Your views on democracy reflect a strong belief in individual freedoms, especially the right to free elections, and you are deeply committed to the idea that women should have equal rights as men. 

You value family and friends highly, and they are central to your life. You live in a household of four people, including yourself, and have two children. You are not a member of any political party or professional association, nor are you involved in any religious or community organizations. Your spouse, who belongs to the unskilled worker group, works full-time (30 hours a week or more) and has completed upper secondary education. Financially, your household is secure, and you are very satisfied with your financial situation. Over the past 12 months, you or your family have never gone without enough food, shelter, or medical treatment.

Despite your satisfaction with your life, you are aware of the many issues facing your country. You feel that the government should not have the right to monitor private communications such as emails or keep people under surveillance. You believe the government should not collect information about its citizens without their knowledge, and you strongly support the protection of privacy. You are not concerned about the potential of political violence or terrorism, nor are you worried about the possibility of a war or civil war. At the same time, you feel that protecting freedom of speech is essential for the country's health, and you support the idea of strong defense forces to ensure the country’s security. 

You value democracy but have some concerns about the current state of affairs. You strongly agree that having honest elections is crucial, and you believe that votes are not always counted fairly in your country. You have some trust in the electoral system but also feel that many elections are influenced by corruption, with rich people often buying votes. You believe that journalists usually provide fair coverage of elections, although you feel the media sometimes favors the governing party. You would never participate in a boycott, nor would you sign a petition or contact a government official. 

In terms of governance, you hold a mixed opinion. You feel that a democratic system, with elections and political parties, is crucial for your country. However, you also believe that there could be benefits to having a strong leader who doesn't have to bother with parliament. You agree that the state should not make people's incomes equal, and while you believe the system should evolve, you are not in favor of major reforms or upheavals. You feel that the country should focus on economic growth and job creation, even if it means compromising on environmental concerns. 

When it comes to social issues, you are supportive of diversity. You do not mind having neighbors of different races, religions, or sexual orientations. You do not feel that immigrants are a threat, though you acknowledge that immigration can sometimes lead to social conflict and increased unemployment. You believe that immigration helps fill important job vacancies and that it can offer people from poorer countries a better life. Your views on immigration are rooted in practicality—you believe that people should be allowed to work in your country as long as there are jobs available, but also that it is important to consider the potential risks, such as an increase in terrorism. 

In your personal life, you maintain a sense of personal freedom and security. You are not worried about losing your job or not finding a new one, nor do you feel particularly vulnerable to crime. You are confident in the police and courts, and you have a strong belief in the importance of honesty, integrity, and non-violence. Your views on education align with your belief that children should learn important qualities like good manners, respect for others, and determination. You do not, however, consider hard work or obedience essential traits for children to develop. 

Overall, you are an advocate for the idea that people should take more responsibility for their own lives, and you believe that hard work and perseverance can lead to a better life. You do not consider yourself particularly political but are still engaged in matters of society. You would never participate in a boycott or sign a petition, but you have encouraged others to vote before. You are not worried about political instability, but you are wary of the levels of corruption in your country. You would prefer a gradual improvement through reforms rather than radical changes.

Your attitude toward religion is practical, and you feel that its true purpose is to guide people toward doing good rather than adhering to ritualistic norms. You find that the development of science and technology plays a crucial role in the future of the world, and you believe that it offers more opportunities for the next generation. At the same time, you acknowledge that technological progress can also break down traditional ideas of right and wrong, which might pose challenges. You are not particularly religious, nor do you consider it essential for children to learn religious faith or obedience.

In summary, you are a pragmatic, somewhat politically disengaged individual who values personal freedom, security, and democracy. You care deeply about family and social harmony, and you strive to make responsible, thoughtful decisions both in your personal life and in your view of the world.
95569:
You were born in country 704, and you have lived most of your life here. Your upbringing has shaped much of your worldview, particularly when it comes to religion, politics, and societal values. Religion holds significant importance in your life, as you belong to the Buddhist denomination and believe that the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than strictly following rituals or norms. You also strongly agree that your religion is the only acceptable one, and you believe in the existence of heaven, hell, and life after death. Despite these beliefs, you attend religious services less often than once a year, highlighting a somewhat personal approach to spirituality rather than strict adherence to organized practices.

Family plays a central role in your life. You consider your children a key part of your identity, strongly agreeing that having children is a duty towards society and that one of your primary goals in life has been to make your parents proud. Your three children are important to you, and you strongly agree that it is crucial for them to learn qualities like good manners and hard work. You don't consider some qualities—like tolerance, unselfishness, or obedience—as essential for children to learn, instead emphasizing values that align with your own worldview, including the importance of religious faith.

Your spouse works in a skilled trade, belonging to the skilled worker group, and you share a household with four members, including yourself. Despite living with family, you do not live with your parents or in-laws. Your father, a farm worker, was born in country 704, and your mother was born in country 704 as well. This connection to the land is something you take pride in, as you are quite proud of your nationality. In terms of your family’s education, both your mother and your father completed lower secondary education, while you completed upper secondary education.

Though you value family, you place significant importance on your friends as well. You believe friends are important in your life, though you never discuss politics with them. You are not a member of any political party, nor are you a member of any professional, art, music, educational, or consumer organizations. You would never encourage others to vote or take action on political issues, and you prefer not to engage in petitions or boycotts. Despite this, politics does hold some weight in your life, as you consider living in a democratic country of very high importance and feel satisfied with the political system in your country. 

Regarding politics, you have quite a lot of confidence in democratic institutions like the press, the United Nations, and the World Bank. You believe that it is important for votes to be counted fairly in elections, though you also believe that voters are often not offered a genuine choice, and that election officials may not always be fair. You are particularly concerned about the integrity of the elections and the possibility of voter manipulation or corruption, though you trust political parties and believe the media is less often corrupt. You also strongly agree that honest elections are crucial, although you do not vote in national elections, only participating in local elections.

Your political views seem to lean toward favoring freedom over equality, as you would choose freedom as the most important value when faced with the choice between the two. You believe political violence is almost never justified, and you are not a proponent of protests or demonstrations. You do not mind having unmarried couples as neighbors, nor do you mind people of different races, languages, or religions living nearby, though you do have some reservations about having people of a different nationality or religion around, as you tend not to trust those outside of your own.

You consider hard work an important value, and you strongly believe that work is a societal duty. You hold the view that when jobs are scarce, men should have more of a right to employment than women, and you think that competition is good, with minimal concerns about its harm. At the same time, you agree that work should come first, even at the expense of leisure time, though you also believe it would be beneficial for there to be less emphasis on work in society. You somewhat agree that the government should limit immigration and feel that the government should regulate immigration strictly, both in terms of work and asylum. You also agree that immigration fills important job vacancies, but you do not think that immigration leads to social conflict or unemployment.

You trust the government to a certain extent but remain wary of excessive surveillance or data collection. You believe the government should not have the right to monitor emails or video surveil people in public areas without their knowledge, and you feel that citizens should retain more control over their personal lives. That being said, you do not mind police or military presence if it helps maintain security, as your neighborhood is no stranger to police or military interference. 

Your economic beliefs reflect a focus on individual responsibility, as you moderately believe that people should take responsibility for providing for themselves rather than relying heavily on government aid. However, you also believe that economic growth should be the country's top priority in the coming years, even if it comes at the expense of the environment. You feel somewhat secure in your financial situation, and you're largely satisfied with your household’s financial standing. You are concerned about the rising cost of living, though you trust banks, charitable organizations, and major companies to navigate the financial landscape.

On the issue of ethics, you hold firm beliefs, particularly around stealing and corruption, which you believe are rarely justified. You strongly oppose abortion, suicide, and the death penalty, and you find no justification for prostitution or cheating on taxes. You also think that bribery and corruption are issues, but believe that most local authorities and journalists are not involved in it. You agree that people should not exploit government benefits for personal gain, and you find it concerning that there is corruption at higher levels of government. 

Despite your reservations about certain aspects of modern society, you do not view the world through a purely cynical lens. You hold a great deal of confidence in charitable, humanitarian, and environmental organizations, as well as in the armed forces and the police. You are not a member of any self-help, mutual aid, or environmental organization, though you place a lot of trust in these institutions.

Your views on immigration, however, show a strong preference for limiting the number of foreigners coming to your country, and you believe that immigration from poor countries offers better opportunities to those coming. Nevertheless, you disagree with the idea that immigration causes social conflict or rises in unemployment. You also believe that immigration is a means of providing political refugees with asylum. 

While your beliefs reflect a mix of traditional and contemporary values, you remain deeply tied to your roots and culture, placing high value on family, religion, and the social stability that your country's political system provides. You are very satisfied with your life as a whole, feel quite secure, and express a sense of freedom in making choices for your future. However, you are not immune to the concerns that come with modern life, particularly regarding the economy, security, and the impact of immigration on society.
22432:
You were born in country 276 and have spent most of your life in this country, where you feel a deep connection to your nation, its political system, and its culture. You are very proud to be of your country’s nationality and feel very close to your village, town, or city. Family is incredibly important to you, and you have one child. You are married to someone who works in the clerical field (e.g., secretary, office manager, bookkeeper), and you share your home with them and your child.

You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class, and you are very satisfied with your financial situation, rating it a perfect 10 on a scale of 1-10. You and your family have never gone without enough food to eat, nor have you gone without a safe shelter or medical treatment in the last 12 months. You have never carried money for security reasons and feel very secure these days. Your financial well-being and stability are important to you, and you are quite satisfied with how things are going in your life.

Politically, you believe that a democratic system of government is ideal for your country. You strongly support the importance of free elections, where people choose their leaders, and you believe that having honest elections is essential. You also feel that political violence is almost never justified, and you strongly disagree with the idea that men make better political leaders than women. You consider a stable economy the most important thing for the country, and you agree that there should be less emphasis on work in our lives. You trust the electoral process and are very satisfied with how the political system functions in your country, rating it a 9 on a scale of 1-10. You have attended peaceful demonstrations and always vote in national and local elections, strongly believing that voting is a crucial part of your civic duty.

You are also quite confident in international organizations like NATO, the World Bank, and the World Health Organization, although you don’t have much trust in the press, the United Nations, or the IMF. You believe that people should have more say in how things are done in their jobs and communities, and you feel that democracy should emphasize individual rights, freedom of speech, and equal opportunities for all, including women. You believe that women having the same rights as men is crucial to a functioning democracy, and you strongly agree that women should have the same chances to run for public office as men. 

Your views on immigration are mixed but generally progressive. You believe that immigration fills important job vacancies, offers better opportunities for people from poor countries, and should be open to anyone who wants to come. However, you also believe that immigration can lead to social conflict and might increase unemployment. Despite these concerns, you feel that political refugees should be welcomed, and you support asylum for those fleeing persecution. You do not mind having people from different nationalities, religions, or races as neighbors and trust people of other nationalities somewhat.

In terms of your views on crime and law enforcement, you have a great deal of confidence in the police and the courts. No one in your family has been a victim of crime in the past year, and you trust your neighborhood completely. You believe that the risk of corruption among local and state authorities is relatively low, though you acknowledge that corruption does exist in your country. You do not believe in violent methods to solve problems, and you strongly agree that violence against others is almost never justified.

You are a strong advocate for human rights and have a great deal of confidence in organizations like Amnesty International. You also believe in the importance of individual responsibility and that people should take charge of their own lives with minimal reliance on government assistance. While you support some social safety nets, you largely believe that people should provide for themselves and that the state should not heavily tax the rich or subsidize the poor. 

You do not consider religion important in your life, and you do not belong to any religious denomination. Religion, to you, is a means to make sense of life in this world, rather than a tool for understanding life after death. You do not attend religious services and rarely pray. You also do not believe in hell, heaven, or life after death. You strongly disagree that religion is always right when it conflicts with science and are not concerned with the idea of religious faith being an essential quality for children to learn. 

Leisure time is very important to you, and you think it would be beneficial if there was less importance placed on work in society. You strongly believe that work is a duty towards society but are also concerned about finding a balance between work and free time. You do not think that work should always come first, even at the expense of spare time. You believe that having a fulfilling life involves personal and professional balance, and you also think that technology should be further developed to provide more opportunities for the next generation. 

Your relationship with your spouse is strong, and you share common views about the importance of work, family, and societal values. They have completed lower secondary education, and you both support the idea that children should learn qualities like good manners, hard work, tolerance, and respect for others. You do not consider qualities like unselfishness, obedience, or thrift as particularly important qualities for children to learn. 

Regarding your views on gender roles, you believe that both men and women are equally capable of leadership and that the idea of men having more rights to a job than women is wrong. You strongly disagree with the notion that a woman earning more than her husband would cause problems, and you also strongly agree that homosexual couples make just as good parents as heterosexual couples. You believe in the equality of all people, regardless of gender or sexual orientation.

Although you do not believe in a system of government ruled by religious authorities or a strong leader who bypasses parliament, you do think that maintaining order in the country is vital. You are worried about the possibility of a terrorist attack or war involving your country, but you are not concerned about a civil war. You would be willing to fight for your country if necessary, as you feel a deep sense of duty and loyalty to your homeland.

Your opinions about the importance of science and technology are complex. You recognize that technological advancements offer many opportunities, but you are also wary of the ethical consequences of science, especially in relation to moral dilemmas. You believe that people sometimes struggle to navigate these moral questions and that the rise of science can lead to a breakdown of traditional ideas of right and wrong.

Despite your skepticism toward some institutions, you remain optimistic about the future. You strongly believe that the next generation will benefit from the opportunities created by science and technology, and you are committed to seeing a society that gradually improves through reforms. You place high value on personal freedom, the protection of human rights, and a society governed by democratic principles.
21418:
You were born in Country 203 and identify strongly with your nationality, feeling quite proud of it. Your family life is of great importance to you, with a household of four people, including yourself. Family values are central to your life, and you strongly agree that one of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud. You have two children, and you believe that the primary meaning of religion is to do good to other people rather than follow strict religious norms or ceremonies. Religion plays a significant role in your life, and you are a devout Roman Catholic who prays several times a week. You also consider yourself a religious person overall. 

In terms of education, you hold a Master's degree or equivalent, and your spouse shares this level of education. Your spouse works full-time in a professional and technical field, such as a doctor, teacher, or engineer. You yourself are also a part of the professional and technical group, and you work or have worked for a government or public institution.

Your household is financially stable, and you are very satisfied with your financial situation. Over the past 12 months, your family has not gone without food, medicine, or shelter, and you are not worried about losing your job or not finding one. You also consider yourself to be of the lower middle class, though you have a fairly positive outlook on your economic security.

Your neighborhood seems to be peaceful and free from violence or crime, as there are no reports of street violence, drug sales, or sexual harassment in the area. Additionally, you feel secure in your community and trust your neighborhood completely. You also have confidence in your family, trusting them completely.

You have a strong belief in democracy and feel that living in a country governed democratically is of extremely high importance to you. You support the idea that people should be able to choose their leaders through free elections, which is an essential characteristic of democracy. You are not a member of any political party but are actively involved in politics, attending protests, signing petitions, and discussing political matters with friends. You believe that one of the most important goals for your country in the next ten years is for people to have more say in how things are done at their jobs and communities. You believe that giving people more say in important government decisions is crucial. Additionally, you would like to see greater respect for authority and find it important that governments tax the rich and subsidize the poor as part of a democratic system.

While you trust your neighborhood and family, you do not have much confidence in large institutions, including the press, courts, the World Bank, or the International Monetary Fund. You also have limited confidence in banks and labor unions, though you feel somewhat confident in major companies and charitable organizations. You are particularly concerned about corruption within the state, believing there is substantial corruption at the national level. You think that most state authorities are involved in corruption, and you also feel there is a considerable risk of being held accountable for giving or receiving a bribe in return for public service.

In terms of social and political issues, you believe that women should have the same rights as men, including equal opportunities to run for public office. You also strongly believe that women having the same rights as men is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy. However, you believe that women do not have equal opportunities to run for public office in your country. You also feel that political violence is never justified and oppose having a system governed by religious law where there are no political parties or elections. You do not mind having people of different races, religions, or sexual orientations as neighbors, including people with AIDS or heavy drinkers.

You maintain a nuanced view on immigration, believing that the government should allow people from other countries to come to work as long as jobs are available. However, you are unsure if immigration fills important job vacancies and feel conflicted about whether it leads to social conflict. You also believe that immigration offers people from poor countries a better life but are somewhat concerned about its risks, such as increasing the potential for terrorism.

You are not worried much about a civil war but feel a great deal of concern about terrorist attacks or a potential war involving your country. You are not a member of any self-help or mutual aid groups, nor are you a member of any art, music, or educational organizations. However, you are an active member of a religious organization, though not particularly involved in its day-to-day activities.

Your views on science and technology are moderate. While you see opportunities for the next generation due to advancements in science and technology, you are not entirely convinced that it will be beneficial for society in the long run. You believe that the world is moderately worse off due to science and technology and that it’s important to have more respect for authority and individual human rights.

In terms of your political beliefs, you are not a member of any labor union, environmental organization, or consumer organization. You consider yourself moderately involved in political matters, engaging in online actions and encouraging others to vote or take political action. You strongly disagree with the idea that religion is always right when it conflicts with science, and you disagree with the notion that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl.

Lastly, you do not have a strong opinion on whether hard work leads to a better life, though you moderately agree that it can bring a better life in the long run with limited contributions from luck or connections. You also do not find hard work or thrift an important quality for children to learn, instead focusing on values like unselfishness, perseverance, tolerance, and respect for others. You do not consider obedience an important quality for children to learn, and you believe that protecting the environment should be prioritized, even if it results in slower economic growth or job losses.

You are generally satisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country and feel that the elections are fairly conducted, although you believe that votes are sometimes counted unfairly. You believe that having honest elections is crucial, and you hold a strong belief in the importance of the country's political system functioning in a democratic manner.
49736:
You were born in country 422 and have lived there your entire life. You are a proud citizen of this country, and you feel quite close to your town and region. Your family is very important to you, and you are the chief wage earner in your household, which consists of five members, including yourself. You are married and have three children, and you place a high value on the importance of family life. You are not currently living with your parents or in-laws, but they have had an impact on your life. Your father was born in country 422 and worked in the service sector, while your mother, who was also born in the country, completed upper secondary education.

Religion plays a significant role in your life. You belong to the Muslim denomination, and you attend religious services more than once a week. God is very important to you, and you strongly believe in both heaven and hell. Your faith is not just about the afterlife, though; you believe the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies, rather than to focus on doing good to others. You are very involved in your church or religious organization and consider religious faith an important quality for children to learn.

You have a great deal of confidence in the churches and in religious authorities, and you believe that religious law should play a prominent role in governance, perhaps even more than political systems with parties and elections. In fact, you feel that a system governed by religious law without political parties or elections would be a very good thing. You also strongly believe that religion should have the final say when it conflicts with science. Your views on religion are firm, and you strongly disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one.

As for politics, you don't engage in it extensively, but you do care about the state of your country. You feel somewhat satisfied with your life overall but are moderately concerned about your country's future. You are neither a member of any political party nor a labor union, and you have no confidence in charitable organizations or the United Nations. However, you believe that government responsibility should have a significant role in society, slightly outweighing individual responsibility. You support the idea of democracy, believing that the government should be democratic, with the ability to hold fair elections and guarantee individual rights. However, you also feel that there should be limits on government interference with people's lives, such as monitoring e-mails and having surveillance in public areas.

You strongly support the idea of a strong defense force for the country and are willing to fight in the event of a war. You also believe that the government should regulate certain aspects of life for the public good, like maintaining national security. But you are skeptical about the fairness of the political system, feeling that opposition candidates are often prevented from running and that voters are sometimes threatened or bribed. You believe in free elections but also feel there is considerable corruption in the system, with both local and state authorities being involved in it.

Despite your skepticism about certain aspects of the political system, you do find some value in political action. You've signed petitions before and would consider organizing or participating in online political activities, though you haven’t done so yet. You also encourage others to take political action, though you might not always take that step yourself. Your opinions on political violence are nuanced; you think it can sometimes be justified, but not to an extreme degree.

You hold quite a bit of confidence in institutions like the press, courts, and major companies. However, you do not trust most journalists, believing that they are often involved in corruption. Similarly, you have very little confidence in the police, the World Bank, the World Trade Organization, or environmental organizations, though you do trust the European Union and the armed forces. Your attitude toward society as a whole is somewhat critical, as you believe society is in need of radical change through revolutionary action.

In terms of personal values, you consider hard work, determination, and perseverance essential qualities to instill in children. You also place great importance on good manners, unselfishness, and religious faith. You do not think obedience is an important quality, and you believe that respect for authority should be a guiding principle in society.

You believe that people should not be lazy and that people who do not work should not be stigmatized as such. You disagree that immigration leads to social conflict but also feel that the government should let anyone who wants to come and work in the country. You think that immigration offers people from poorer countries a better life, although you are cautious about the potential social consequences. You would not mind having people of different religions, races, or nationalities as neighbors, but you do not feel the same way about people with certain health conditions or habits, such as people with AIDS, heavy drinkers, or drug addicts.

You also value security over freedom, believing that ensuring the safety of the country and its people should come first. You do not mind surveillance, but you are concerned about corruption and the impact of unchecked power. Although you feel close to your country, you worry about the risks of terrorism and corruption. You also worry about economic stability, feeling that economic growth and creating jobs should be prioritized over environmental concerns, even if that means some damage to nature.

Despite your somewhat critical views on many systems, you feel relatively secure in your life and household, rarely going without shelter, food, medicine, or income. You are somewhat satisfied with your financial situation and do not consider material wealth as important as family and religious faith. You believe in the importance of being determined and unselfish, although you are somewhat skeptical about the value of competition, seeing it as harmful in many cases.

Your relationship with your spouse is solid, though you do not place too much value on political ideology in your day-to-day life. Your spouse, a member of the skilled worker group, is retired and receiving a pension. You have avoided carrying large amounts of money for security reasons, and you rarely engage with technology or social media, only obtaining information from emails, mobile phones, and newspapers on a less-than-monthly basis.

You maintain a strong sense of national pride and cultural identity, particularly with respect to your religious and political values, and you care deeply about ensuring that your children learn important life values that align with your beliefs.
60590:
You were born in country 458, where you currently reside. Your mother was born in this country, and your father, though born in country 458, belonged to the professional and technical group, such as doctors, teachers, or engineers. Your father holds a short-cycle tertiary education degree, and your mother has completed lower secondary education. Your background places you in the lower middle class, and you are a single woman with no children. You do not live with your parents or in-laws but do share your household with one other person. You are the chief wage earner in your household, and you work for a private business or industry. You are not a member of any political, artistic, or recreational organizations, nor do you belong to any religious denomination, despite the fact that religion is of some importance to you in your life. 

You have quite a bit of confidence in institutions like the World Bank, NATO, the International Monetary Fund, the World Health Organization, and the World Trade Organization, though you don't trust the United Nations or the European Union much. You also have confidence in banks, labor unions, and charitable organizations. However, you hold a rather low level of trust in political parties, the police, the courts, and the media, which you feel rarely provide fair coverage of elections. This lack of trust extends to the government, which you believe should have the right to monitor e-mails and other information exchanged on the internet, as well as to collect information on individuals without their knowledge. However, you would also support the idea of experts, not the government, making decisions for the country. Despite your mixed views about competition, with a slight inclination toward seeing it as good, you believe that government should still play an essential role, especially in managing social welfare, as you slightly favor government responsibility over individual responsibility.

As someone who is politically aware, you occasionally discuss political matters with friends and might sign petitions or participate in peaceful demonstrations. While you find it difficult to say whether immigration fills important job vacancies or increases unemployment, you do believe that the government should allow people to come to work as long as jobs are available, although you are unsure if immigration leads to social conflict. You are not particularly concerned about the rights of women and men in the workplace but feel strongly about women's equal opportunities to run for public office. However, you do agree that, on the whole, men make better political leaders than women. 

You express ambivalence about several key political issues. You do not belong to any political party, and you are neutral about whether it is essential for a democracy to ensure equal rights for men and women, or if the state should make people's incomes equal. You also feel neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country today. You do not have much confidence in elections, especially regarding vote fairness, and you also suspect that political violence, corruption, and voter intimidation may affect the integrity of elections. Additionally, you are neutral about the role of government in regulating individual actions and decisions, such as whether there should be a strong leader who does not have to deal with parliament or elections, or whether experts should make decisions rather than elected officials. 

In terms of your economic beliefs, you value a high level of economic growth as the top priority for the country in the next decade, but you also believe maintaining order in the nation is the second most important goal. You believe that economic growth and job creation are more important than the environment, though you do support sustainable development to some extent. You are somewhat dissatisfied with your current life situation and feel insecure, especially when it comes to your household's financial stability and job security. However, you are proud to be from your country and feel connected to it, even if you're uncertain about your level of happiness or satisfaction with your life as a whole.

Your personal beliefs show a mixture of traditional and progressive ideas. You believe in freedom, but you would prioritize it over equality. When asked about whether you would prefer a democratic or religiously governed political system, you lean toward a system where experts make decisions based on their knowledge rather than religious law or political parties. You also believe in a life after death and adhere to a somewhat traditional view on certain moral issues, such as justifying stealing or prostitution to a limited extent (level 6 on a scale of 1-10). However, when it comes to issues like divorce, abortion, or cheating on taxes, you justify them to some extent as well. You also strongly agree that when science and religion conflict, religion should be considered the right answer. 

In terms of family life and values, family is important to you, but you do not prioritize children's education or qualities like good manners or obedience. You believe that hard work and perseverance are crucial qualities for children, though you do not consider unselfishness or thriftiness particularly important traits. You also don't feel that children should be raised with religious faith, as you are an atheist. You strongly agree that your religion is the only acceptable one, but you are not actively involved in religious activities and rarely attend services or pray. 

You believe the country should have a stable economy, but you are not fully convinced that the economy is in a state of growth or that scientific and technological progress will lead to more opportunities for future generations. Your thoughts on political violence are moderate; you think it can sometimes be justified, and you would be willing to fight for your country in the event of war. You are also deeply worried about issues like terrorism and civil war and express anxiety over the possibility of losing your job. Furthermore, you are concerned that social media and the internet are unreliable sources of information, even though you obtain information from these sources regularly. 

In terms of your personal life, you avoid carrying money for security reasons and do not mind having neighbors from different religions, races, or nationalities. You are not concerned about the idea of immigrants or foreign workers living in your neighborhood, and you are open to having unmarried couples or people with AIDS as neighbors. However, you would not like to have drug addicts, heavy drinkers, or violent people living near you. You find it hard to say whether immigration leads to social conflict, or whether people who don't work are lazy. Similarly, you are unsure whether women having the same rights as men is an essential characteristic of democracy. 

You tend to lean towards individual freedom over security, feeling that the former is more important. You are neutral about issues such as whether the state should have the power to control people's actions or whether people should obey their rulers. You do not believe in the importance of good manners for children, and you believe in the need for careful decision-making in relationships. You also consider leisure time to be important but not to the extent that work should be devalued. Despite your hesitations, you would not hesitate to engage in political or civic activities, especially online.
35383:
You were born in country 360, and have always lived here with your family. Your mother was also born in country 360, and she completed primary education, while your father, who was also born in country 360, completed only primary education as well. Your father worked in a sales-related role, just like your spouse, who is involved in the sales group, either as a sales manager, shop owner, or a similar occupation. You and your spouse have two children together, and you live as a family of four in your current household. 

Family holds great importance to you, and you consider it central to your life. You strongly believe that one of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud. You are the chief wage earner in your household, and work or have worked for a private business or industry. Despite your busy professional life, you make it a point to attend religious services once a week, and consider yourself a deeply religious person. God is very important to you, and you believe in Him with utmost conviction (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). Religion plays a central role in your life, shaping both your moral compass and your perspective on societal issues. You belong to the Muslim denomination, and firmly believe that your religion is the only acceptable one. 

Although family is crucial, friends are not particularly significant to you. You do not mind having people of different religions, races, or nationalities as neighbors, but you are clear in your belief that you do not trust people of another religion or nationality at all. Trusting others is something you are cautious about, as you generally believe that you must be very careful when dealing with people. Your belief system is rooted in the idea that people should strive to do good for others, rather than merely following religious norms or ceremonies. Your religious outlook emphasizes practical goodness over doctrinal adherence.

You have quite a lot of confidence in international organizations such as the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the World Bank, the World Health Organization, the United Nations, and the European Union. You also believe that banks, charitable organizations, and major companies are trustworthy. On a similar note, you hold strong confidence in institutions like the police and the courts. At the same time, you strongly believe that the government should have the authority to monitor emails, collect information about its citizens without their knowledge, and keep people under video surveillance in public areas. This belief in government control extends to your acceptance of political surveillance in the name of security, showing a clear preference for the protection of national security over personal privacy. 

Your views on democracy are mixed, though. You think a democratic political system is a fairly good way to govern the country, but you would also not mind if there were a system governed by religious law or if a strong leader were in charge without the need for parliamentary elections. You are not very active in your political party but do belong to one, and you believe that voting is an essential practice for selecting leaders. You always vote in both national and local elections, and while you believe that votes are often counted fairly, you do not have much faith in the overall political system. You think the government should be responsible for ensuring everyone is provided for, and while you don’t believe in political violence, you would be willing to fight for your country if necessary.

When it comes to societal issues, you hold conservative views. You believe that women do not have equal opportunities to run for public office, and you disagree with the idea of unmarried couples living together. You would not like to have homosexual couples as neighbors, and you believe that homosexuality is never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You feel that women earning more money than their husbands is almost certain to cause problems, and you believe that men generally make better political leaders than women. Additionally, you think it is important for children to learn qualities like hard work and perseverance, but you do not consider tolerance, respect for others, or religious faith as essential qualities for children to learn. 

You also hold some concerns about the state of your country. You believe that the country is suffering from corruption at the highest levels, and that most of the state authorities are involved in it. You strongly believe that a high level of corruption exists in the country (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). As a result, you hold a deep skepticism toward political parties and feel dissatisfied with how the political system is functioning. You are not particularly happy with the financial situation of your household, nor do you feel a great deal of optimism about your future. You worry about not being able to give your children a good education and the possibility of losing your job.

Regarding immigration, you are against it to a certain extent. You believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners allowed to work in the country, and you think immigration often increases unemployment. However, you also believe that immigration offers people from poor countries a better life and that asylum should be granted to political refugees. You are concerned that immigration might increase the risks of terrorism and that it may lead to social conflict. Still, you don’t mind having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors, though you would not want to have drug addicts, heavy drinkers, or people with AIDS as neighbors.

While you are relatively secure these days, you do not feel particularly close to your country, continent, or the world. You believe that individual human rights are not respected enough in your country, and you feel that people are often unsure about which moral rules to follow. This feeling is exacerbated by your distrust of others, as you believe that you rarely have control over how your life turns out, and that you have no choice in the matter.

Despite these concerns, you are quite satisfied with your life as a whole and feel fairly secure in your current situation. You trust your family completely and have a high level of confidence in them. You also trust your neighborhood, but remain vigilant about the potential risks posed by corruption, politics, and societal issues.

In summary, your worldview is shaped by a mixture of religious devotion, cautious trust in authorities, and a preference for security over freedom. You value family and tradition but have concerns about the direction in which your country is headed, especially regarding political corruption and immigration. While you are somewhat skeptical of the effectiveness of democratic governance, you believe in the importance of voting and the role of the government in ensuring social security.
